   131.01 APPOINTING AUTHORITY OF THE MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall have authority to appoint individuals to fill vacant
positions within all departments not under the control of the Finance Director,
the Law Director, or Council, and, with respect to Category I employees, shall
have the authority to establish initial compensation, including eligibility for
applicable benefits, prior to confirmation by Council in accordance with the
Exhibit I compensation schedule of the general payroll ordinance; however,
prior to confirmation by Council, such initial compensation may be awarded at
no greater step level than Step 3 of the existing Exhibit I compensation
classification for the vacant position until such time as Council sets
permanent compensation. Such appointments shall be submitted to Council for
confirmation, by resolution or ordinance, within thirty days of the appointment
and recommendation by Personnel Board of Review. After the establishment of the
initial compensation for Category I employees, either by the Mayor or through
the confirmation process of Council, the compensation for such Category I
employees shall be in accordance with the City’s general payroll ordinance. The
initial compensation and benefits for non-Category I employees as well as the
compensation and benefits thereafter shall be as provided in the applicable
City payroll ordinances. The appointing authority established herein shall be
subject to applicable Civil Service rules and regulations.
(Ord. 1997-166. Passed 10-23-97.)
CHAPTER 132
Department of Human Resources
132.01   Established; organization.
132.02   Director established; responsibilities.
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR. 4.18
   132.01 ESTABLISHED; ORGANIZATION.
   There is hereby established a Department of Human Resources. The Department
shall consist of the Director of Human Resources and additional personnel as
the City Council authorizes. These additional personnel shall be appointed by
the Director and shall be subject to removal by him or her. (Ord. 2023-115.
Passed 7-13-23.)
   132.02 DIRECTOR ESTABLISHED: RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)    Appointment. The Director shall be a full-time employee appointed by
and be answerable to the Mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of
the City Council.
   (b)    Qualifications. The Director shall have at least five (5) years of
human resource management experience and shall hold a minimum of a bachelor's
degree in human resources, business administration, or public administration.
   (c)    Duties. The Director shall have the following responsibilities which
may from time to time be added to or diminished by City Council:
      (1)    Personnel. The Director shall recommend, evaluate, and participate
in staff development for the City. The Director shall coordinate recruitment
efforts with Department Heads, accept resumes and applications, and assist with
the interview process. The Director shall develop a master employment
application form which shall be used in all departments containing vital
information necessary to administer the personnel records of the City. The
Director shall be responsible for creating and ensure the completion of an
Annual Review Process to evaluate the job performance of each permanent non-
bargaining employee of the City. The Director shall also maintain a file of
such records, which file shall include for each employee, evaluations, rewards,
disciplinary actions, commendations and any other correspondence or pertinent
information that may from time to time come to the attention of the Director
with respect to any specific employee.
         The Director shall assist department heads in carrying out their
responsibilities regarding personnel matters. The Director shall establish a
uniform system of maintaining accurate records for all employees dealing with
the use and accumulation of all leave types available to employees.
         The Director shall be responsible for the administration and
coordination of all employee benefits for all departments within the City. The
Director shall be the City's Privacy Officer per Health Insurance Portability &
Accountability Act (HIPAA) regulations.
         The Director shall be responsible for maintaining all records for the
processing of claims for Workers' Compensation and unemployment compensation.
The Director shall, when it is appropriate, appear before the State agencies
responsible for Workers' Compensation and unemployment compensation,
representing the City's interest relative to claims made for unemployment and
Workers' Compensation.
      (2)    Equal Employment Opportunity. The Director shall be responsible
for maintaining any and all records with respect to the compliance by all
departments regarding both employment and contracts with the City with equal
employment opportunity requirements of both the State and Federal Government.
      (3)   Insurance. The Director shall maintain in his or her office the
master copy of hospitalization and life insurance policies maintained by the
City, , as well as other employee benefit plans or coverage which may from time
to time be obtained by the City.
      (4)   Risk Management. The Director shall be responsible for
administering and overseeing risk management programs, policies, and functions.
The Director shall periodically review and make recommendations to the Mayor
and City Council for improvement of City policies, procedures, and practices on
personnel matters. The Director shall communicate changes in City personnel
policies and procedures to department heads, and periodically, as appropriate,
further communicate with said department and division heads to monitor
compliance with said personnel policies and procedures.
      (5)   Public Meetings. The Director shall attend all regular and special
meetings of the Civil Service Commission and to be a resource to the Commission
on all matters before it. Attend the meetings of other City boards,
commissions, committees and Council upon direction by the Mayor.
      (6)   Annual Report on Staffing. On the date of submission of the annual
budget estimate, or within fourteen (14) days thereafter, the Director shall
submit a written report of anticipated staffing to City Council for the
forthcoming calendar year, covering all City staffing of full-time, seasonal,
temporary, and part-time (less than 1040 hours annually) employees. The report
shall contain:
         A.   The anticipated staffing by classification/position for the year
in which the report is produced,
         B.   The actual number of employees in each listed classification/
position as of the date of the report and shown in the City Organizational
Charts adopted by City Council,
         C.   An indication of each classification/position on the report that
was never filled during the previous year from which the report is produced.
         D.   The anticipated staffing by classification/position for the
forthcoming calendar year, and
         E.   The average merit increases awarded to non-bargaining employees
under Chapter
115 for the current year, including the number of employees who received above
the average, the average, or below average, and
         F.   The amount included in the annual budget submitted to Council for
approval for merit increases for non-bargaining employees.
         The report of anticipated staffing will be advisory only, except that
the anticipated number of employees in any classification/position will not be
exceeded, and new positions will not be created, without first providing a
revised report that clearly indicates the staffing adjustments to City Council
for approval. The annual report on staffing and any revisions will be placed on
file with the Clerk of Council. In the event of an absence or vacancy of a
Director of Human Resources, the annual report on staffing shall be provided by
the Mayor.
         (Ord. 2023-115. Passed 7-13-23.)

   133.01 ORGANIZATION.
   The Department of Finance of the City of Stow as established by
Article IV of the Charter of the City of Stow, shall consist of two divisions;
namely the General Division and the Income Tax Division, under the
administration of the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 1995-231. Passed 10-21-95.)
   133.02 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF FINANCE AND DEPUTY FINANCE DIRECTOR APPOINTED.
   (a)   Assistant Director of Finance-General Division. The General Division
shall consist of one Assistant Director of Finance-General Division, who shall
be appointed by the Finance Director and shall be in the unclassified service,
who shall assist the Director of Finance in the performance of his duties and
who shall perform such duties as may be assigned him by the Director of
Finance. The Division shall also consist of those other full-time or part-time
employees or such other employees that are deemed necessary by the Finance
Director upon the approval of Council. The Finance Director shall have
authority to appoint individuals to fill vacant positions within the
Department; such appointments shall be submitted to Council for confirmation,
by resolution or ordinance, within thirty days of the appointment and
recommendation by Personnel Board of Review, and, with respect to Category I
employees, shall have the authority to establish initial compensation,
including eligibility for applicable benefits, prior to confirmation by Council
in accordance with the Exhibit I compensation schedule of the general payroll
ordinance; however, prior to confirmation by Council, such initial compensation
may be awarded at no greater step level than Step 3 of the existing Exhibit I
compensation classification for the vacant position until such time as Council
sets permanent compensation. After the establishment of the initial
compensation for Category I employees, either by the Finance Director or
through the confirmation process of Council, the compensation for such Category
I employees shall be in accordance with the City’s general payroll ordinance.
The initial compensation and benefits for non-Category I employees as well as
the compensation and benefits thereafter shall be as provided in the applicable
City payroll ordinances. The appointing authority established herein shall be
subject to applicable Civil Service rules and regulations.
   (b)   Deputy Finance Director-Income Tax Division. The Income Tax Division
of the Department shall consist of one Deputy Finance Director-Tax
Administrator, who shall be appointed by the Finance Director and shall be in
the unclassified service of the City, who shall assist the Director of Finance
in his duties, particularly as pertains to the collection and administration of
the Municipal Income Tax, and who shall perform such duties as may be assigned
to him by the Director of Finance. The Division shall also consist of those
other full-time or part-time employees or such other employees that are deemed
necessary by the Finance Director upon the approval of Council. The Finance
Director shall have authority to appoint individuals to fill vacant positions
within the Department; such appointments shall be submitted to Council for
confirmation, by resolution or ordinance, within thirty days of the appointment
and recommendation by Personnel Board of Review, and, with respect to Category
I employees, shall have the authority to establish initial compensation,
including eligibility for applicable benefits, prior to confirmation by Council
in accordance with the Exhibit I compensation schedule of the general payroll
ordinance; however, prior to confirmation by Council, such initial compensation
may be awarded at no greater step level than Step 3 of the existing Exhibit I
compensation classification for the vacant position until such time as Council
sets permanent compensation. After the establishment of the initial
compensation for Category I employees, either by the Finance Director or
through the confirmation process of Council, the compensation for such Category
I employees shall be in accordance with the City’s general payroll ordinance.
The initial compensation and benefits for non-Category I employees as well as
the compensation and benefits thereafter shall be as provided in the applicable
City payroll ordinances. The appointing authority established herein shall be
subject to applicable Civil Service rules and regulations.
(Ord. 1999-152. Passed 9-9-99.)
   133.03 ASSUMPTION OF DUTIES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 135.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2023-116,
passed July 13, 2023.)
   133.04 DUTIES OF ASSISTANT FINANCE DIRECTOR AND DEPUTY FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   The duties, obligations and responsibilities of the Assistant Finance
Director and Deputy Finance Director are hereby affirmed as follows:
   (a)   The Assistant Finance Director and Deputy Finance Director, upon
request, shall attend regular and special meetings of Council and, upon
request, shall attend meetings of Council committees.
   (b)   The Assistant Finance Director and Deputy Finance Director shall
attend meetings of City boards or commissions, upon the request of the Finance
Director or direction of the President of Council.
   (c)   At the direction of the Finance Director, the Assistant Finance
Director and Deputy Finance Director may act as advisors for the officers,
boards and commissions of the City as pertains to the functions and
administration of the City.
   (d)   The Assistant Finance Director and Deputy Finance Director shall make
themselves available not less than forty hours during each and every week,
i.e., five, eight hour days, for financial matters affecting the affairs of the
City and make themselves available for additional necessary consultation and
services throughout the week for other City financial affairs as necessary.
However, the Finance Director, if deemed necessary, shall have the authority to
revoke the reduction of hours provision as herein contained.
   (e)   The Assistant Finance Director and Deputy Finance Director shall
perform all other duties as are consistent with this office and the directives
of Council, and such duties which are not in conflict with the provisions of
the ordinances of the City and as are generally imposed upon City finance
officers by the Ohio Revised Code, upon such terms and conditions as Council
shall establish.
      (Ord. 1999-152. Passed 9-9-99.)
   133.05 ACTING DIRECTOR.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
133.05 which was comprised of Ordinance 1997- 152 expired as of midnight
December 31, 1997.)
   133.06 DIRECTOR'S REPORTS TO COUNCIL.
   (a)   Pursuant to Section
6.03 of the City Charter, the Director of Finance is directed to prepare and
present monthly to Council a certified report, by fund or by control, based
upon the actual proof balances shown by the books and records, regarding the
financial affairs of the City and containing the following facts:
      (1)   The actual cash balance in each fund and control as of the
beginning of the current fiscal year;
      (2)   The budget's estimated income by fund and control for the current
fiscal year;
      (3)   The balances of the budget's estimated income to be received;
      (4)   The actual receipts to date of the certified report;
      (5)   The actual expenditures to date of the certified report;
      (6)   The actual cash on hand in the depository accounts or invested
pursuant to law;
      (7)   The actual outstanding encumbrances to date of the certified
report; and
      (8)   The unencumbered cash positions to date of the certified report.
   (b)   Pursuant to Section
6.03 of the City Charter, the Director is directed to prepare and present to
Council at the end of each fiscal period a certified report, based upon the
bond and note register, regarding the indebtedness of the City and containing
the following facts:
      (1)   A detailed statement of debt by issue and the original date of each
bond and note issue;
      (2)   The original amounts of each bond and note issue;
      (3)   The amount of each bond and note issue outstanding;
      (4)   The total amount of indebtedness;
      (5)   The amount of indebtedness available under statutory limitations;
and
      (6)   Such supplementary data as the Director considers necessary to
properly inform Council of the debt structure of the City. (1979 Code 31.10)
   133.07 TREASURY INVESTMENT ACCOUNT.
   (a)   Whenever the Director of Finance submits to the Mayor and to the Law
Director a statement of moneys in the City Treasury or in the process of
collection and a schedule showing the probable requirements of money for use by
the City for a period of not less than six months, together with a
recommendation as to whether any moneys in the Treasury shall be invested in
the various types of bonds or obligations enumerated in Ohio R.C. 731.56, the
Mayor, the Law Director and the Director of Finance may thereupon order the
investments, at not more than the current market value, as they deem advisable
in the interest of the City.
   (b)   The Director of Finance shall maintain an account, to be known as the
Treasury Investment Account, in which he shall enter all transactions relating
to the investment of treasury funds. He shall maintain a record and furnish to
Council a duplicate of all items entered thereon, showing any bonds or other
securities purchased or sold for the account, with the number, maturity, date
and interest rate of each.
(1979 Code 31.11)
   133.08 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   The Investment Policy for the City of Stow as attached to Ordinance 1996-171
as Exhibit A is adopted and fully incorporated herein. A copy of the Investment
Policy shall remain on file in the Finance Director’s, Law Director’s, Mayor’s
and City Council offices.
(Ord. 1996-171. Passed 10-10-96.)
   133.09 RED FLAG RULES ADOPTED AS IDENTITY THEFT POLICY.
   (a)   The Red Flag rules as attached to original Ordinance 2009-194, are
hereby adopted for implementation by the City of Stow for programs and services
offered by the City of Stow where account information is maintained by the City
of Stow including water billing and EMS transportation.
 
   (b)   The Finance Director is directed to implement the program not later
than November 1, 2009.
 
   (c)   The Law Director, on advice from the Finance Director, is hereby
authorized to make minor and necessary changes to the Red Flag rules for
specific customization of City services. (Ord. 2009-194. Passed 9-10-09.)
CHAPTER 135
Department of Public Service
135.01   Organization; Acting Director.
135.02   Refunds for municipal permits.

CROSS REFERENCES
      Department of Public Service - see CHTR.
Art. VII
      Director to be member of Board of Control - see ADM.
173.01
   135.01 ORGANIZATION; ACTING DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Department of Public Service, as established by
Article VII of the City Charter, shall consist of:
      (1)   The Director of Public Service, as provided in
Article VII of the City Charter;
      (2)   The Assistant Service Director, who shall be appointed by the Mayor
and confirmed by Council who shall be in the unclassified service of the City,
shall assist the Director of Public Service in the performance of his duties
and shall perform such duties as may be assigned to him by the Director; and
      (3)   The Deputy Director of Public Service, who shall be appointed by
the Mayor and confirmed by Council and who shall be in the unclassified service
of the City, shall assist the Director of Public Service and the Assistant
Service Director in the performance of their duties and shall perform such
duties as may be assigned to him by the Director or the Assistant Service
Director; and
      (4)   Those full-time or part-time employees as are deemed necessary by
Council upon the recommendation of the Director.
   (b)   The Assistant Public Service Director shall become the Acting Director
of Public Service with all of the powers and duties of the Director in the
event that, and during such time as, the Director is unable for any cause or
reason to perform the duties of his office. The determination that the Director
is unable to perform the duties of this office shall be made by the Mayor.
Following this determination, the subsequent determination that the Director is
able to perform his duties, thereby relieving the Assistant Service Director of
the powers and duties of the Director and returning the powers and duties to
the Director, shall be made by the Mayor.
   (c)   The Deputy Director of Public Service shall become the Acting Director
of Public Service with all of the powers and duties of the Director in the
event that, and during such time as, the Director and Assistant Public Service
Director is unable for any cause or reason to perform the duties of his office.
The determination that the Director is unable to perform the duties of this
office shall be made by the Mayor. Following this determination, the subsequent
determination that the Director is able to perform his duties, thereby
relieving the Assistant Service Director or the Deputy Director of Public
Service of the powers and duties of the Director and returning the powers and
duties to the Director, shall be made by the Mayor.
   (d)   The Director of Public Service shall, notwithstanding any other
provisions of the Codified Ordinances in conflict herewith, be authorized to
designate the Chief Building Official of the City, as the same may, from time
to time, exist or be modified, subject to approval by the Board of Building
Standards of the Department of Industrial Relations of the State in accordance
with OBBC 4101:2-1-45(C), as the same may be from time to time amended.
(Ord. 1995-183. Passed 6-22-95.)
   135.02 REFUNDS FOR MUNICIPAL PERMITS.
   It shall be the policy of the City to refund moneys paid and deposited with
the City for any municipal permit issued for any department under the
jurisdiction of the Director of Public Service when it clearly appears to the
Director that the reason for which the permit had been granted has been
abandoned by the holder thereof or has become moot for any reason and when the
permittee has requested a refund from the City. In these instances the Director
may authorize a return of the whole or a lesser amount of the funds advanced in
payment for the permit. However, the actual overhead costs incurred by the City
to the date of refund shall be first deducted from the moneys paid and the
balance shall be remitted to the permittee, after which time the permit shall
be considered as officially lapsed. The Director of Finance is authorized to
make those refunds when and as the same are approved in writing by the Director
of Public Service and in the amounts specified in the written approval for
refund.
(1979 Code 31.16)
   135.03 ANNUAL REPORT ON STAFFING.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
135.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2023-116, passed July 13, 2023.)

   137.01 MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   The City Engineer shall be a graduate of an approved engineering
curriculum of four academic years or more from a school or college approved by
the State of Ohio Board of Registration for Professional Engineers and
Surveyors and who has four or more years of experience of a type necessary to
the State of Ohio Board of Registration for Professional Engineers and
Surveyors, as well as State certification as a professional engineer under the
statutes of the State.
(Ord. 1985-265. Passed 8-8-85.)
   (b)   The City Engineer shall be appointed by the Director of Public Service
with the advice and consent of the Mayor. However, before the appointment
becomes final, Council shall confirm the same and may authorize contractual
duties and responsibilities. The Director of Public Service shall be the
executive head of the Department of Engineering and shall manage and supervise
the functions thereof. Subject to appropriation by Council, the Director may
employ, from time to time, the assistants, consultants and employees as may be
necessary for the proper discharge of the duties and the execution of the work
of the Department.
(1979 Code 31.20)
   137.02 DUTIES.
   The Department shall perform those duties as are imposed by Section
7.03 of the City Charter upon the Director of Public Service and which he deems
necessary, as the needs of the City require, to delegate thereto.
(1979 Code 31.21)
   137.03 DIRECTOR TO KEEP RECORDS.
   The Director shall keep a complete record of all proceedings within the
Department, a copy of which, certified by him, shall be competent evidence in
all courts, and shall report to Council, as it requests from time to time, the
duties and work therein performed.
(1979 Code 31.22)
   137.04 FLOOD AND MUDSLIDE HAZARDS.
   The City Engineer shall have the following responsibilities and authority
to:
   (a)   Delineate or assist the administrator of the National Flood Insurance
Act of 1968, at his request, in delineating the limits of the areas having
special flood or mudslide hazards on available local maps of sufficient scale
to identify the location of building sites;
   (b)   Provide such information as the Administrator may request concerning
present uses and occupancy of the flood plain or mudslide area;
   (c)   Maintain for public inspection and to furnish, upon request, with
respect to each area having special flood hazards, information on elevations,
in relation to mean sea level, of the lowest floors of all new or substantially
improved structures;
   (d)   Cooperate with federal, state and local agencies and private firms
which undertake to study, survey, map and identify flood plain or mudslide
areas and to cooperate with neighboring communities with respect to the
management of adjoining flood plain or mudslide areas in order to prevent the
aggravation of existing hazards;
   (e)   Submit, on the anniversary date of the community's initial
eligibility, an annual report to the Administrator on the progress made during
the past year within the community in the development and implementation of
flood plain or mudslide area management measures; and
   (f)   Take other official action as may be reasonably necessary to carry out
the objectives of the program.
      (1979 Code 31.23)
   137.05 FEE FOR INSPECTION OF WORK IN CITY RIGHT OF WAY.
   All persons, businesses, corporations, associations and partnerships that
engage in the business of making improvements, repairs, maintenance,
construction, reconstruction, or work of any kind within the municipal right of
way or upon lands dedicated or to be dedicated to the City, which therefore
require the inspection of the Department of Engineering as to compliance with
municipally approved plans, profiles and specifications, shall obtain permits
as required by ordinance.
(1979 Code 31.24)
   137.06 PREVAILING WAGE COORDINATOR.
   The City Engineer is designated as the Prevailing Wage Coordinator as
required by Ohio R.C. 4115.071.
(1979 Code 31.25)
   137.07 CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS FOR PUBLIC WORKS.
   The standards of construction for all public works of the City shall be
enforced by the City Engineer and shall be adhered to upon all public lands or
lands in which the public has an interest, and shall be those standards set
forth in the State Department of Transportation manual entitled "Construction
and Material Specifications" as the same is kept current by the State
Department of Transportation with only the following exceptions: that as
pertains to the construction of storm sewers, storm sewer inlets, storm sewer
design and manholes, the City Engineer may elect, and has sole discretion, to
use the standards specifically proposed by the office of the Summit County,
Ohio, County Engineer, or the City Engineer's own typical cross-section design
and specific material criteria now on file in the office of the Clerk of
Council.
(1979 Code 31.26)

Art. VIII
   139.01 DIRECTOR.
   The Mayor shall be the executive head of the Department of Public Safety
until that time as Council appoints some other person to that office. The
Director shall be the chief administrative officer of the Police Department and
the Fire Department and shall make and publish written rules for the government
of the Police and Fire Departments, and the conduct and discipline of members
thereof.
(Ord. 1997-239. Passed 12-18-97.)
   139.02 AGE REQUIREMENTS FOR POLICE AND FIREMEN.
   All applicants for original appointment to the Police Department shall have
reached the minimum age of twenty-one years, but no person shall be eligible to
receive an original appointment to the Police Department on and after his
fortieth birthday. All applicants for original appointment to the Fire
Department shall have reached the minimum age of twenty-one years, but no
person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment to the Fire
Department on and after his thirty-sixth birthday. However, there shall be no
maximum age limitation for those persons originally appointed or promoted to
the office of Chief of Police or Fire Chief within the Department of Public
Safety unless the limitation is prescribed by the Civil Service Commission or
the appointing authority. Further, all applicants for original appointment
shall continue to be subject to the other provisions of Ohio R.C. 124.41 and
124.42 and to the general Civil Service rules and regulations established by
the Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 2021-236. Passed 12-16-21.)
   139.03 FEE FOR POLICE AND FIRE REPORTS.
   There is established a compensatory fee for reimbursement to the City for
all reports and documents furnished from time to time to any person in the
normal course of Fire Department or Police Department business, which reports
are in the nature of replica or photostatic copies of original reports, are
otherwise available for use and inspection by those persons, and are not
confidential and restrictive files of the Fire Department or Police Department.
The fees are not applicable to reports furnished to other law enforcement or
fire agencies. The fees for such reports are based on a daily total and are as
follows:
 
Copies of Police and Fire Reports:
1-19 pages                      No Charge
Copies of reports will be mailed only if requestor encloses a self-addressed
stamped envelope.
20 pages                        $1.00 plus $.05 per page in excess of 20 pages.
Video Reproduction              Actual Costs (Up to 1 week waiting period)
Photograph Copies               Actual Costs (Up to 1 week waiting period)
Cassette & Micro Cassette       Actual Costs (Up to 1 week waiting period)
                                Five Dollars ($5.00)
Stow Police Dept. Record Checks Requires a Photo ID or a letter containing a
                                signed waiver/release authorization.
 
(Ord. 2014-148. Passed 11-20-14.)
   139.04 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS REQUIRED.
   Each full-time employee in the Police Department and the Fire Department
shall have an annual physical examination performed by the City Physician, as
scheduled by the Chiefs of each Department. The City shall pay the first
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) of any professional medical fee so charged and
shall thereafter equally share the cost thereof with the employee. However, the
City's share shall not exceed fifty-two dollars and fifty cents ($52.50) per
physical examination per employee.
(1979 Code 31.38)
   139.05 FEE FOR GLASS ETCHING. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
139.05 was repealed by Ordinance 2014-147.
   139.06 STOW YOUTH SERVICES: SEALING OF DIVERSION RECORDS AND ENROLLMENT FEE.
   (a)    Any juvenile who successfully completes a diversion program with Stow
Youth Services shall be entitled to the immediate sealing of all criminal
records associated with their participation in the program. For the purposes of
this provision, "seal" means to remove the criminal record(s) from Stow's main
file or similar records and to secure it in a separate file that is accessible
only to the juvenile court.
   (b)   All juveniles applying to a diversion program with Stow Youth Services
must submit a one-time enrollment fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for admission
into the program. If the applicant is denied admission or otherwise does not
meet the requirements to gain entrance into the program, the enrollment fee
shall not be charged or, if charged, must be refunded in its entirety. Once the
applicant is admitted and enrolled in the program, the enrollment fee is non-
refundable. (Ord. 2012-121. Passed 8-9-12.)

   ORGANIZATION

8.03
ORGANIZATION
   141.01 ACTING POLICE CHIEF.
   Pursuant to Sections
4.18 and
12.01 of the City Charter, there is established the full-time, nonclassified
position of Acting Police Chief which shall be utilized at such times as there
is a vacancy in the position of Police Chief. The Mayor shall have the
authority to appoint any full-time officer of the Police Department to this
office at such time as no permanent Police Chief is in office and until a
permanent Police Chief is appointed. While the police officer fulfills the
position of Acting Police Chief, he shall have all the duties, responsibilities
and powers of the Chief and shall receive a salary established and approved by
Council.
(1979 Code 34.01)
   141.02  COMMUNITY SERVICE OFFICERS.
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to appoint qualified personnel
to perform general unclassified duties within the Department of Public Safety,
so as to fulfill the authorized positions of Community Service Officer and, if
necessary, Assistant Community Service Officer, consonant with the salary
appropriations of Council. However, job descriptions shall be in the noncivil
service, nonclassified and noncompetitive service of the City. These personnel
shall serve at the sole discretion of the Director of Public Safety. Any
personnel fulfilling these offices at the time of this enactment who are
extended civil service coverage shall continue to retain that coverage in that
position, but all subsequent personnel hired to the job descriptions shall not
be accorded civil service status.
(Ord. 2006-87. Passed 6-8-06.)
   141.03 PERSONNEL AND ADMINISTRATIVE RANKINGS.
   The City Police Department is reorganized and shall consist of the following
personnel and administrative rankings:
     (a)   One Police Chief, as authorized by Section
8.03 of the Charter, who shall be appointed by the Director of Public Safety
subject to applicable civil service provisions. The person holding the rank of
Police Chief shall, within six months after the completion of the one-year
probationary period, become a resident of the City and remain for so long as he
shall hold the full-time position.
   (b)   One Acting Police Chief when appropriate and authorized in conformity
with the terms of Section
141.01, except that notwithstanding Section
141.01, he shall be an officer who is subject to the applicable civil service
provisions of his permanent rank which he shall continue to possess while
acting as Chief.
   (c)   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may appoint not more
than two captains, who shall be appointed subject to applicable civil service
provisions.
   (d)   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may appoint not more
than four lieutenants, who shall be appointed subject to applicable civil
service provisions.
   (e)   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may appoint not more
than ten sergeants, who shall be appointed subject to applicable civil service
provisions.
   (f)   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may appoint not more
than sixty- three patrol officers, who shall be appointed subject to applicable
civil service provisions.
   (g)   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may appoint not more
than twenty special police officers.
   (h)   The Police Chief may appoint one secretary to the Police Chief. The
position shall be in the noncompetitive, unclassified service. The secretary
shall perform those duties as may be prescribed by the Chief of Police and who
shall be appointed by, and serve at, the pleasure of the Police Chief. The
person presently holding the office of secretary to the Police Department under
civil service regulations shall continue in that position but only until the
expiration of the term of office and thereafter the office shall be filled as
herein provided.
      (Ord. 2004-24. Passed 1-22-04.)
RESERVE POLICE UNIT
   141.04 APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   There is created within the Department of Public Safety a Reserve Police
Unit, the members of which shall be appointed by the Mayor, acting as Director
of Public Safety, and the members of which shall not exceed fifty in number.
(1979 Code 34.05)
   141.05 TERM OF SERVICE.
   Reserve police officers shall serve so long as the Mayor, acting as Director
of Public Safety may direct, or until a resignation submitted by the members
shall be accepted by the Mayor acting as Director of Public Safety.
(1979 Code 34.06)
   141.06 QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS.
   The members of the Reserve Police Unit may not be under the age of nineteen
years of age at the time of their appointment, and those other requirements as
provided in the appendix to this chapter.
(1979 Code 34.07)
   141.07 CONTROL OF UNIT.
   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the Reserve Police
Unit and shall have control of the assigning, training, stationing and
directing of work of the Unit. The Reserve Police Unit shall have all police
powers; they shall not, normally, have powers of arrest or bear firearms,
except that the Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, may confer the
power of arrest and the right to carry firearms at those times of emergency or
peril as he deems appropriate. The Reserve Police Unit shall perform those
other duties as are assigned by the Chief of Police and shall act only when in
the prescribed uniform or portion of uniform. The Chief of Police shall
prescribe the time and place the uniform or portion thereof shall be worn. The
Reserve members shall obey the chain of command of the Police Department and
shall take orders from all regular appointed members thereof.
(1979 Code 34.08)
   141.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, shall prescribe the rules
and regulations for the organization, administration, conduct and control of
the Reserve Police Unit.
(1979 Code 34.09)
   141.09 UNIFORM.
   The Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety, is authorized to prescribe,
by the rules and regulations, the type of uniform or part thereof which shall
be worn by members of the Reserve Police Unit.
(1979 Code 34.10)
   141.10 SERVICE ON VOLUNTARY BASIS; COMPENSATION.
   All service performed by reserve policemen shall be on a voluntary basis and
within the City. Reserve policemen shall be paid thirty five dollars ($35.00)
per month.
(Ord. 2006-19. Passed 1-26-06.)
   141.11 NONLIABILITY.
   This section is declared by Council as an exercise by the City of its police
powers for the protection of public peace, health, property, safety and general
welfare. Neither the City, nor agent, nor representative of the City; an
officer appointed under the provisions of this section; or any individual,
firm, partnership, corporation or the receiver or trustee or any other agent
thereof, who in good faith, executes any executive order, rule or regulations
promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be liable for
injury or damage sustained to person or property as the direct or proximate
result of that section.
(1979 Code 34.12)
SPECIAL POLICE
   141.12 AUTHORITY TO APPOINT.
   The Mayor, as the Director of Public Safety, may appoint and commission at
his discretion, with the prior approval of the Chief of Police, Special Police,
known as Plant Protection Guards, who shall have the power to arrest on public
or private premises in commercial, mercantile, industrial or educational
establishments, and who shall otherwise supplement and assist the Police
Department in the apprehension, while in hot pursuit, of persons committing
misdemeanors or felonies. Special Police shall have the rights, privileges,
immunities and obligations extended to regular members of the Department,
subject to the limitations hereinbefore and hereinafter specified. Every person
so appointed and commissioned shall first secure a permit from the Mayor, as
the Director of Public Safety, which permit shall be revocable by the Mayor, as
the Director of Public Safety, for cause. When the Mayor is contemplating such
a revocation, he shall send, by registered mail, notification of a hearing to
the permittee involved; this hearing shall be held at least five days before
the effective date of the revocation.
(1979 Code 34.15)
   141.13 PERMIT REQUIRED; REVOCATION.
   (a)   Every person so appointed and commissioned shall first secure a permit
from the Mayor, acting as the Director of Public Safety.
   (b)   The permit shall be revocable by the Mayor, acting as the Director of
Public Safety, for cause. When the Mayor is contemplating a revocation, he
shall send, by registered mail, notification of a hearing to the permittee
involved, which hearing shall be held at least five days before the effective
date of the revocation.
(1979 Code 34.16)
   141.14 PERMIT APPLICATION; BOND.
   (a)   Application for Permit. (There shall be no charge for the permit
required by Section
141.13 of this chapter.)
      (1)   No person shall engage in Special Police duties, as a plant
protection guard, unless and until the permit has been first issued.
Applications for these permits shall be obtained from the office of the Chief
of Police. Application shall include, but not be limited to, the following
information:
         A.   Fingerprints of the applicant;
         B.   A photograph of the applicant; and
         C.   The past addresses and past employment of the applicant.
      (2)   In addition, each applicant, at the time of filing the application,
shall be twenty-one years of age or older.
   (b)   Bond. Those applicants who are granted a permit by the Mayor, acting
as Director of Public Safety, shall, before their commission is effective, post
with the City a surety bond in favor of the City in the amount which shall be
set, from time to time, by legislative authority, to indemnify against
malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in office.
(1979 Code 34.17)
   141.15 EXTENT OF AUTHORITY; CREDENTIALS.
   (a)   The powers herein granted to the Special Police, known as plant
protection guards, shall extend only to private premises and hot pursuit from
private premises. Further, the rights, privileges, immunities and obligations
herein granted to these plant protection guards shall be effective only so long
as the permittee is employed by private business interests to act as a security
policeman, and these privileges shall terminate at the death, retirement or end
of tenure for any cause of the permittee.
   (b)   The permittee, acting as a security policeman for a private business,
shall carry upon his person a badge, along with other credentials to be
furnished by the private business, which shall specify the police capacity of
the permittee. In addition, if the permittee is in uniform, he shall wear, upon
his left shoulder, an identification shield designating the identity of the
employer.
(1979 Code 34.18)
   141.16 CLAIMS FOR PERSONAL INJURY.
   No permittee, herein authorized to be commissioned and appointed as a
Special Police plant protection guard, shall, by virtue of his duties, have any
claim for or upon the City or upon any division of the County or the State, by
and through the special commission herein granted, arising out of any damage or
personal injury sustained by the permittee in the course of his employment as a
special plant protection guard. No such permittee shall have any claim upon the
Police Pension Fund under Ohio R.C. Chapter 742.
(1979 Code 34.19)
CHAPTER 143
Fire Department
143.01   Fire Chief and Acting Fire Chief.
143.02   Fire force.
143.03   Auxiliary Force.
143.04   Volunteer Firemen's Dependent Fund.
143.05   Radio Dispatcher; Public Safety Communications Supervisor.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Fire Department - see CHTR.
8.04
   143.01 FIRE CHIEF AND ACTING FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)   The Fire Department shall, as authorized by Section 8.04 of the City
Charter, consist of a Fire Chief who shall be the chief administrative officer
and supervisor of the Department. The Fire Chief shall be appointed by the
Director of Public Safety in accordance with the civil service laws, from those
individuals eligible for that position either from within or outside the Fire
Department. Such person holding the position of Fire Chief at the time of this
enactment shall be deemed qualified for that position under the civil service
provisions of the Charter. Within six months after the completion of the one-
year probationary period, the person holding the rank of Fire Chief shall
become a resident of the City and remain for so long as he shall hold the full-
time position.
(Ord. 2001-242. Passed 12-13-01.)
   (b)   Pursuant to Sections
4.18 and
12.01 of the City Charter, there is established the full-time nonclassified
position of Acting Fire Chief, which shall be utilized at such times as there
is a vacancy in the position of Fire Chief. The Mayor shall have the authority
to appoint any full-time officer of the Fire Department to this office at such
time as no permanent Fire Chief, is in office, and until a permanent Fire Chief
is appointed. While the fire officer fulfills the position of Acting Fire
Chief, he shall have all the duties, responsibilities and powers of the Chief
and shall receive a salary established and approved by Council.
(1979 Code 35.00)
   143.02 FIRE FORCE.
   (a)   In addition to the Fire Chief and Acting Fire Chief, the Fire
Department shall consist of the following fire force:
      (1)   Not more than two Division Fire Chiefs.
      (2)   Not more than one Fire Marshal.
      (3)   Not more than eight Captains.
      (4)   Not more than thirteen Lieutenants.
      (5)   Not more than sixty Firefighters/Paramedics.
      (6)   Part time Firefighters/Paramedics as needed.
   (b)   All members of the fire force shall be appointed by the Mayor, acting
as Director of Public Safety, subject only to applicable civil service
provisions of the City Charter.
   (c)   All members of the fire force shall be in the classified service.
(Ord. 2009-127. Passed 6-25-09.)
   143.03 AUXILIARY FORCE.
   (a)   Members of the Auxiliary Fire Force shall be appointed by the Fire
Chief with the approval of the Mayor, acting as Director of Public Safety.
   (b)   Members shall not be classified under civil service nor be required to
meet civil service requirements such as age.
   (c)   Members shall be trained in every phase of fire fighting and shall be
required to attend all regular and special drills of the Fire Department with
compensation as determined by Council.
   (d)   Members shall be provided with the necessary protective clothing and
equipment by the City.
   (e)   When performing any duties required by the Fire Chief, other than
attendance at drills, members shall be compensated at an appropriate hourly
rate a determined by Council.
(1979 Code 35.02)
   143.04 VOLUNTEER FIREMEN'S DEPENDENT FUND.
   (a)   There is established a Volunteer Firemen's Dependent Fund Board in and
for the City.
   (b)   The Volunteer Firemen's Dependent Fund Board shall consist of five
members as follows:
      (1)   Two members of Council;
      (2)   Two members elected by the volunteer firemen; and
      (3)   One elector of the City, elected by the Board members appointed in
subsection (b)(1) and (2) hereof. This elector shall not be a public employee,
a Council member or a Fire Department member.
   (c)   Vacancies occurring in the Board shall be filled as provided in Ohio
R.C. 146.03
   (d)   The term of each Board member shall be one year. The first appointment
shall continue to and through January 1, 1979. Thereafter each Board member
shall serve a full term of one year.
   (e)   The legal advisor for the Volunteer Firemen's Dependent Fund Board
shall be the City Law Director.
   (f)   The Finance Director is authorized to establish a Volunteer Firemen's
Dependent Fund by rotary trust account. This trust account is assigned No. 40-
27, and shall deposit into the Fund the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00),
the payment being made to the State Treasurer.
   (g)   The beneficiaries and benefits of the Volunteer Firemen's Dependent
Fund shall be:
      (1)   The widow of a volunteer firemen killed in the discharge of his
duties, in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000) plus one hundred dollars
($100.00) per month so long as she remains his widow.
      (2)   To the mutual guardian or other person upon whom a child of a
volunteer firemen is dependent for child support, the sum of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per month until that dependent child is sixteen years old,
unless that child is regularly attending a recognized secondary school, in
which case the payment shall continue until the child is eighteen years old or
has completed secondary education, whichever is earlier; or
      (3)   To a volunteer fireman, duly and permanently disabled while in the
discharge of his duties as a volunteer fireman, the sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) per month, unless during that period as a volunteer fireman he may be
under full salary during the term of his disability.
   (h)   The State Treasurer is designated as the custodian of the Volunteer
Firemen's Dependent Fund and all disbursements and proceeds, to the extent that
they are not otherwise in conflict herewith, shall be governed by the terms and
provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 146.
(1979 Code 35.03)
   143.05 RADIO DISPATCHER; PUBLIC SAFETY COMMUNICATIONS SUPERVISOR.
   The Director of Public Safety is authorized to appoint qualified personnel
to perform general classified duties within the Department of Public Safety, so
as to fulfill the authorized positions of Radio Dispatcher, and Public Safety
Communications Supervisor, consonant with the salary appropriations of Council.
The job description shall be in the civil service, classified and competitive
service of the City.
(Ord. 1993-40. Passed 1-28-93.)

145.02   Appointing authority of the Law Director.
CROSS REFERENCES

   145.01 REVIEW OF BID PACKAGES BY THE LAW DIRECTOR.
   The Law Director shall review all completed City bid packages prior to any
such release for formal competitive public bidding as specified in Section
7.04, Charter, and Section
173.05, C.O.S. Such review shall be completed within ten business days.
(Ord. 1996-132. Passed 7-11-96.)
   145.02 APPOINTING AUTHORITY OF THE LAW DIRECTOR.
   The Law Director shall have authority to appoint individuals to fill vacant
positions within the Department of Law, and, with respect to Category I
employees, shall have the authority to establish initial compensation,
including eligibility for applicable benefits, prior to confirmation by Council
in accordance with the Exhibit I compensation schedule of the general payroll
ordinance; however, prior to confirmation by Council, such initial compensation
may be awarded at no greater step level than Step 3 of the existing Exhibit I
compensation classification for the vacant position until such time as Council
sets permanent compensation. Further, with respect to the part time position of
prosecutor, compensation shall be equal to the existing rate of pay for said
position at the time of appointment. Such appointments shall be submitted to
Council for confirmation, by resolution or ordinance, within thirty days of the
appointment and recommendation by Personnel Board of Review. After the
establishment of the initial compensation for Category I employees, either by
the Law Director or through the confirmation process of Council, the
compensation for such Category I employees shall be in accordance with the
City’s general payroll ordinance. The initial compensation and benefits for
non-Category I employees as well as the compensation and benefits thereafter
shall be as provided in the applicable City payroll ordinances. The appointing
authority established herein shall be subject to applicable Civil Service rules
and regulations.
(Ord. 1997-168. Passed 10-23-97.)
CHAPTER 147
Department of Development
147.01   Organization.   
147.02   Director established; responsibilities.
147.03   Economic Development Coordinator established; responsibilities.
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR.
4.18
   147.01 ORGANIZATION.
   The Department of Development is established for the purpose of planning for
the maximum utilization of the City's human, economic and natural resources.
The Department shall recommend on all such matters to the Planning Commission
and other City boards, commissions and officers upon request of the Mayor. The
Department shall consist of a Director of Development and those other personnel
as Council authorizes. This additional personnel shall be appointed by the
Director and shall be subject to removal by him.
(1979 Code 31.40)
   147.02 DIRECTOR ESTABLISHED; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)    The position of Director of Development is established as a
nonclassified position in the service of the City, and the Mayor is authorized
to appoint the Director subject to confirmation by a majority of the members of
Council.
   (b)   The Director shall have the following responsibilities, to:
      (1)    Attend all regular and special meetings of the Planning Commission
and to advise the Commission on all matters before it;
      (2)    Attend the meetings of City boards, commissions, committees and
Council upon direction by the Mayor;
      (3)    Act as planning advisor to officers of the City;
      (4)    Assist in promoting and bringing about the right kind of
development in the City;
      (5)    Perform all other duties as are consistent with his office; and
      (6)    Be available at his office within City Hall at those reasonable
times as are requested by the Mayor.
      (7)    Be responsible for the issuance of all zoning permits, supervise
the administration and enforcement of all zoning ordinances as the same may be
delegated to him by the Director of Public Service.
         (Ord. 2021-111. Passed 6-10-21.)
   147.03 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COORDINATOR ESTABLISHED; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The position of Economic Development Coordinator is established as a
non-classified position in the service of the City, and the Mayor is authorized
to appoint the Economic Development Coordinator subject to confirmation by a
majority of the members of Council.
   (b)    The Economic Development Coordinator responsibilities shall include:
      (1)    Maintain a database of information resulting from an annual
survey, onsite business retention and expansion calls and other independent
research on Stow industries.
      (2)    Prepare an annual report on the state of the Stow economy, update
the Community Profile on a biannual basis, and prepare quaiierly reports on new
commercial and industrial investment in Stow.
      (3)    Submit annual budget for economic development activities as part
of annual budgetary process.
      (4)    Maintain economic development web page on City's webpage.
Specifically, maintain update inventory of available buildings, vacant land,
and other features on a daily basis.
      (5)    Maintain active participating memberships with regional
development organizations.
      (6)    Establish and maintain regular communication with industrial and
commercial brokers, realtors, developers, and other economic development
coordinators on available properties. Provide prompt response to leads
generated by the Ohio Department of Development.
      (7)    Update and maintain economic development marketing materials.
      (8)    Preparation of a monthly report for Council to be given during a
Planning Committee meeting.
      (9)    To conduct an on-going program of business retention calls to Stow
industries.
   
   (c)    The duties listed in subsection (b) are the core responsibilities of
the Economic Development Coordinator and may be supplemented and prioritized at
any time by the Director of Planning and Development or the Mayor.
(Ord. 2021-111. Passed 6-10-21.)

BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 159
General Provisions
159.01   Meetings.
159.02   Equitable balance.
159.03   Appointments made by Mayor and Council; letter form    required.
159.04   Appointment when a vacancy occurs for more than ninety days.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Authority to establish - see CHTR.
4.18
         Removal of members - see CHTR.
21.02
         Notification of meetings - see ADM. Ch.
111
   159.01 MEETINGS.
   All meetings of any board, commission, agency or authority created by the
Charter or by action of Council are declared to be public meetings which must
be open to the public at all times. No resolution, ordinance, rule, regulation
or formal action of any kind shall be adopted at any executive session of any
such board, commission, agency or authority.
(1979 Code 32.01)
   159.02 EQUITABLE BALANCE.
   (a)   All appointive boards, commissions and committees heretofore or
hereafter established by law or resolution of this Municipality shall reflect,
as much as possible, an equitable balance. The current make-up of the board
shall be considered, and effort shall be made when reviewing new applicant’s to
create diversity among the membership of our boards, commissions, and
committees.
   (b)   The ultimate decision on appointment, shall remain with the appointing
authority or authorities for such board, commission, or committee.
   (c)   An exception to this section may be made on boards, commissions or
committee whose members are required to hold professional or trade licenses or
meet certain educational requirements necessary to serve on those bodies.
   (d)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit an individual
from completing a term for which the person was appointed.
(Ord. 2020-143. Passed 10-8-20.)
   159.03 APPOINTMENTS MADE BY MAYOR AND COUNCIL; LETTER FORM REQUIRED.
   All appointments made by the Mayor and Council shall be sent to the
appropriate committee of Council in letter form. Said letter must contain the
following information:
   (a)   Full name of appointee,
   (b)   Address of appointee’s residence,
   (c)   Term of appointment, and,
   (d)   The Codified Ordinances’ section or Charter section that authorized
the Mayor to appoint.
   Upon receipt of said request for appointment confirmation by Council shall
be deemed complete upon consideration of said appointment or appointment’s via
motion at the new business portion of Council meeting and an affirmative vote
thereon.
(Ord. 1995-48. Passed 2-9-95.)
   159.04 APPOINTMENT WHEN A VACANCY OCCURS FOR MORE THAN NINETY DAYS.
   (a)   In the event the Mayor fails to make a Mayoral appointment to a Board
or Commission within ninety days of a vacancy, this Council is hereby
authorized to make such an appointment. Likewise, should Council fail to make
one of its Board or Commission appointments within ninety days of a vacancy,
the Mayor shall be authorized to make such appointment.
   (b)   This section shall apply to the following Boards and Commissions: Arts
Commission, Consumer Protection Board, Historical Preservation Review
Commission, Income Tax Board of Review, Public Safety Services Commissions,
Urban Forestry Commission, Civil Rights Commission, Electrical Examiners Board,
Heating and Air Conditioning Examiners Board, and Public Safety Services
Commission.
(Ord. 1997-151. Passed 9-11-97.)
CHAPTER 161
Civil Service Commission
161.01   Establishment.
161.02   Membership; term.
161.03   Powers and duties.
161.04   Classified and unclassified service.
161.05   Suspension of Chief of Police or Fire Chief.
161.06   Limiting constituency served.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Civil Service Commission - see CHTR.
Art. XII
      Police Chief - see CHTR.
8.03
      Fire Chief - see CHTR.
8.04
      State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 124
      Notification of meetings - see ADM. Ch.
111
   161.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   In compliance with
Article XII of the City Charter and Ohio R.C. 124.40, there is established a
Civil Service Commission and a civil service system for the City.
(1979 Code 32.10)
   161.02 MEMBERSHIP; TERM.
   The Civil Service Commission shall consist of three members who are electors
of the City, not more than two of whom shall be adherents of the same political
party. These members shall be appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by
Council, one for a term of two years, one for a term of four years and one for
a term of six years. Each alternate year thereafter the Mayor shall appoint one
person as successor to the member whose term expires to serve six years. A
vacancy during the term of any member shall be filled for the unexpired term in
the manner authorized for an original appointment.
(1979 Code 32.11)
   161.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Civil Service Commission shall prescribe, amend and enforce rules
not inconsistent with Ohio R.C. Chapter 124 for:
      (1)   Classification of positions in the civil service of the City;
      (2)   Examinations and resignations;
      (3)   Appointments, promotions, removals, transfers, layoffs,
suspensions, reductions and reinstatements; and
      (4)   Standardization of positions and maintenance of efficiency.
   (b)   The Commission shall exercise all other powers, perform all other
duties, and have all authority granted with respect to the civil service of the
City as are prescribed by the Revised Code and conferred by law upon the
Director of State Personnel and the State Personnel Board of Review regarding
the civil service of the State.
   (c)   The procedure applicable to reductions, suspensions and removals, as
provided in Ohio R.C. 124.33 and 124.34, shall govern the civil service system.
   (d)   Council, pursuant to Section
12.01 of the City Charter, grants and delegates to the Civil Service Commission
the right, power and duty to organize and carry out the provisions of the civil
service laws enumerated in Ohio R.C. Chapter 124 for those positions determined
to be within the classified service of the City. Council specifically grants to
the Civil Service Commission the right, power and duty to:
      (1)   Adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for its efficient
administration and operation which may differ from Ohio R.C. Chapter 124,
provided that Council confirms these departures from state law by ordinance or
resolution;
      (2)   Receive position or class specifications from the City
administration and thereafter establish by directive who shall be eligible to
apply for a position within the classified service and what the minimum
qualifications for each job category shall be;
      (3)   Establish its own method for the conduct of its meetings, which
method shall include the right to set the dates thereof and to which method
Robert's Rules of Order shall apply unless the Commission directs otherwise;
      (4)   Act as a hearing board in the appeal of disciplinary actions as
provided by Ohio R.C. Chapter 124 or by the rules of the Commission, to modify,
affirm or dismiss the orders of the appointing authority and to establish rules
for the conduct of these hearings;
      (5)   Clearly define who is within and without the classified,
noncompetitive service of the City, to adopt rules for the conduct of its
examinations and the grading thereof prior to the date of the testings, to
establish minimal physical qualifications, to establish application procedures,
to establish and perpetuate rules pertaining to eligible lists, to establish
rules and procedures for the certification of personnel and to provide for
temporary appointments, transfers, reinstatements, layoffs, reductions,
suspensions and removals, and for any other such proceedings in the
administration of its duties as it deems necessary;
      (6)   Provide a penalty for violation of its rules;
      (7)   Have secretarial service and budgetary allocations made to it in
the conduct of its business; and
      (8)   Comply and enforce all provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 124, when it
has no rules which depart therefrom.
         (1979 Code 32.12)
   161.04 CLASSIFIED AND UNCLASSIFIED SERVICE.
   (a)   In compliance with Section
12.01 of the City Charter requiring that Council provide which employees of the
City are within the unclassified service and which are within the classified
service:
      (1)   The unclassified noncompetitive service shall consist of the
following positions, which shall not be included in the classified
noncompetitive service and which shall be exempt from all examinations
required:
         A.   All persons elected by popular vote and all persons appointed to
fill vacancies in such office;
         B.   The members of all boards and commissions established pursuant to
and in compliance with the City Charter or state law;
         C.   The heads of departments appointed by the Mayor pursuant to and
in compliance with the City Charter or state law;
            (Ord. 1985-264. Passed 8-8-85.)
         D.   The Director of Development, Senior Planner, the Director of
Finance, the Assistant Director of Finance,the Deputy Director of Finance-Tax
Administrator, the Director of Public Safety, the Director of Public Service,
the Deputy Director of Public Service, the City Engineer, the Senior Engineer,
the Road Superintendent, the Acting Road Superintendent, the General Road
Foreman, the Law Director, the Deputy Law Director, the Director of Parks and
Recreation, the Parks Supervisor, the Recreation Supervisor, the Electrical/
Building Inspector, Inspection Supervisor and Clerk of Council;
            (Ord. 1987-162. Passed 5-28-87.)
         E.   Special Police Officers;
         F.   Two executive secretaries for the Department of Public Service
and one executive secretary for each other department head, which secretary or
secretaries shall be personally appointed by the department head; and
         G.   Part-time and seasonal employees.
            (Ord. 1985-264. Passed 8-8-85.)
      (2)   The classified service shall consist of all persons in the
employment of the City not specifically included in the unclassified service
and to be designated as the competitive class and the unskilled labor class.
         A.   The competitive class shall include all positions and employments
in the City for which it is practicable to determine the merit and fitness of
applicants by competitive examinations.
         B.   The unskilled labor class shall include ordinary unskilled
laborers. Vacancies in this class shall be filled by appointment from lists of
applicants registered by the Civil Service Commission.
            (1979 Code 32.13)
   (b)   In compliance with Section
12.01 of the City Charter, any person who has served the City in any position
included in the classified service for at least thirty days preceding the
establishment of the Civil Service Commission (Ordinance 1961-4, passed January
12, 1961) shall retain his position without examination until discharged,
reduced, promoted or transferred in accordance with the rules or regulations of
the Commission.
(1979 Code 32.13)
   161.05 SUSPENSION OF CHIEF OF POLICE OR FIRE CHIEF.
   As provided by Ohio R.C. 124.40, the Mayor shall have the exclusive right to
suspend the Chief of Police or the Fire Chief for any of the reasons therein
enumerated and in compliance with the procedure set forth in that section.
(1979 Code 32.14)
   161.06 LIMITING CONSTITUENCY SERVED.
   Effective as of 12:01 a.m., July 29, 1988 and continuing thereafter until
otherwise ordered by Council, the Civil Service Commission is hereby instructed
not to provide services to the School District and/or its employees.
(Ord. 1988-211. Passed 7-28-88.)

   163.01 COMPOSITION AND ORGANIZATION.
   The composition, terms of members, organization and meetings of the Parks
and Recreation Board shall be subject to and as provided in
Article XIII of the City Charter.
(Ord. 2021-48. Passed 5-27-21.)
   163.02 PROCEEDINGS OF PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD.
   Subject to the provisions of
Article XIII of the City Charter, all meetings of the Parks and
Recreation Board shall be open to the public. The presence of three (3) or more
members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business, and
action by the Board on any matter shall be effected by the concurring votes of
at least three members.
(Ord. 2021-48. Passed 5-27-21.)
   163.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE BOARD.
   (a)   In addition to the provisions set forth in Article XIII, Section
13.03 of the City Charter, the Municipality shall operate and maintain public
parks and public lands acquired or designated by Council. For the purpose of
this Code, the Parks and Recreation Board is given the following additional
powers and duties, for the purpose of making recommendations as to the
following matters:
      (1)    To adopt and recommend to Council a Parks Master Plan for the
physical development or redevelopment of the City's park system.
      (2)    To review plans for the development or redevelopment of parks and
recreation facilities as established in Section
163.05 of this Code.
      (3)    The naming or renaming of parks and recreation facilities as
established in Section
163.05 of this Code.
      (4)    To investigate and to recommend to Council on its own initiative
such amendments as it may deem consistent with the purposes of this code and
which further public health, safety, and the general welfare of Stow.
      (5)    The Parks and Recreation Board shall organize, establish, and
adopt its own rules for the time and place for the holding of regular and
special meetings, for the transaction and disposition of its business and the
exercise of its powers, and shall keep records of its recommendations and
determinations.
      (6)    To establish and adopt fees for the use of parks and recreation
facilities as established in Section
 163.05 of this Code.
      (7)    To recommend general policy to Council and the Mayor for the
management and execution of recreational programming for the community, and for
the use of facilities and equipment used for said recreational programs. Rules,
regulations and policies recommended by the Parks and Recreation Board shall be
subject to approval by the Mayor. Labor and equipment to perform maintenance
work for parks and recreation programs and to maintain facilities shall be
subject to the administrative control of the Mayor, and the supervision of the
Director of Parks and Recreation.
      (8)    If any provisions or language set forth herein conflict or are not
in conformance with the Charter of the City of Stow, the Charter shall govern.
   (b)   As used in this section: "Development and Redevelopment" is defined as
the construction, completion, restoration, reconstruction, expansion, or
extension of.
(Ord. 2021-48. Passed 5-27-21.)
   163.04  ESTIMATE OF REVENUE AND EXPENDITURES.
   The Director of Parks and Recreation will review with the Parks and
Recreation Board an
estimate of contemplated revenue and expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year.
(Ord. 2021-48. Passed 5-27-21.)
   163.05 PARK AND RECREATION FACILITIES.
   As used in this section:
   (a)   "Park facilities" includes all land and buildings owned or controlled
by the City of Stow and used for park or recreation purposes including, but not
limited to rental facilities, lodges, shelters, playgrounds, bike and hike
trails, ball courts and ballfields at the following locations, and at any
future parks or recreation locations, including those which may be
inadvertently omitted herein:

      (4)   Stow Senior Center

      (6)   Kid Station
      (7)   Crestdale Park
      (8)   Northport Park
      (9)   Meadowbrook Lake Park
      (10)   City Center Campus (excluding City Hall and Safety Center)
      (11)   Arboretum
      (12)   Heather Hills Park
      (13)   Sherwood Acres Park
      (14)   Partridge Highlands Park
      (15)   Oregon Trail Park
      (16)   Wetmore Neighborhood Park
      (17)   Adell Durbin
      (18)   Silver Springs Park
         (Ord. 2021-48. Passed 5-27-21.)

CHAPTER 171
Urban Forestry Commission
171.01   Establishment of Stow Tree    District.
171.02   Establishment and membership of Commission.

171.05   Procedures.
