an appeal, a hearing shall be held before the Mayor within thirty (30) days of
the date the City received the licensee's request to appeal. The licensee shall
have the right to appear at such hearing, to be represented by counsel, and
have the right to examine and cross examine witnesses. In the event of a
decision and ruling adverse to the licensee, the licensee, unless otherwise
expressly provided, shall have the right to appeal such decision and ruling to
a court of competent jurisdiction, under the authority of and pursuant to the
provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 2506.
   (c)   Whenever, for any cause, a license is revoked or suspended, the City
of Stow shall not issue another license to the licensee until the expiration of
at least one year from the date of revocation of the license.
   (d)   Persons continuing to operate as a mobile ice cream vendor after a
license has been denied, suspended, or revoked pursuant to this chapter may be
served with a cease and desist order issued by a court of competent
jurisdiction, in addition to or in place of criminal penalties found in Section
 739.99. (Ord. 2017-89. Passed 9-28-17.)
   739.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever recklessly violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor of the third degree for a first offense. Any subsequent violation
of this chapter by the same person shall be punishable as a misdemeanor of the
first degree.
(Ord. 2017-89. Passed 9-28-17.)
CHAPTER 741
Private Haulers
741.01   Permit required.
741.02   Application for permit; issuance.
741.03   Certificate of insurance.
741.04   Noncompliance; impounding; permit revocation.
741.05   Prevention of spillage required.
741.06   Waste and recycling districts and collection schedule.
741.07   Hours of collection.
741.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Disposal and transportation upon public ways - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20 et
seq.
      Vehicle loads leaking, etc. - see TRAF.
339.08
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
   741.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in the business or occupation of collecting or
removing garbage, animal or vegetable refuse, ashes, rubbish, trash or waste
materials of any kind within the City and upon its streets without obtaining a
permit to do so and complying with the requirements of this chapter.
(1979 Code 118.01)
   741.02 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Whoever desires a permit to engage in any business described in
Section
741.01 shall make written application at the office of the Director of Public
Service, on forms provided, correctly stating the following:
      (1)   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant;
      (2)   A brief description of the type of materials to be collected and
removed.
   (b)   Each applicant must provide a written notarized affidavit to provide
that all vehicles used for collection are in safe operating condition and has
equipment thereon to meet the requirements of Ohio R.C. Chapter 4513 and
Chapter
337 of the Traffic Code for operational safety for such type of motor vehicle.
   (c)   Upon receipt of affidavit and payment by the applicant to the Director
of Public Service a one hundred dollar ($100.00) permit application fee, the
Director shall issue to the applicant a permit, valid from the date of issuance
to June 15 of the following year.
   (d)   Each permit holder shall be required to post with the City a ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) surety bond to insure their faithful performance
to duties required of them under this chapter, and the City ordinances
regulating vehicular traffic in the City, as well as trash disposal.
   (e)   Each licensed hauler shall conspicuously place or cause to be placed
on his trash trucks the company name, as contained on the permit, in letter
size of not less than eight inches, together with a telephone number.
(Ord. 2005-173. Passed 10-13-05.)
   741.03 CERTIFICATE OF INSURANCE.
   A certificate of insurance shall be filed with the application covering
public liability and automobile liability in the amounts of five hundred
thousand dollars ($500,000) per person for bodily injury and one million
dollars ($1,000,000) per accident for bodily injury and one million dollars
($1,000,000) per accident for property damage.
(Ord. 2005-173. Passed 10-13-05.)
   741.04 NONCOMPLIANCE; IMPOUNDING; PERMIT REVOCATION.
   Any motor vehicle licensed in accordance with this chapter and subsequently
found by the Police Department not to be in compliance with the requirements of
this chapter, may be impounded. In such case the licensee shall be ordered to
comply with such requirements. Upon his failure to do so, the Director of
Public Service, upon recommendation of the Police Department, may revoke the
licensee's permit
(1979 Code 118.04)
   741.05 PREVENTION OF SPILLAGE REQUIRED.
   No permit shall be issued for any motor vehicle not equipped with an
adequate covering, a tarpaulin or other material suitable for serving as an
effective cover to prevent materials collected therein from blowing from or
falling off the motor vehicle, or for any motor vehicle whose bed or body
construction or containers are not properly constructed to prevent dropping or
leaking of the materials collected therein.
(1979 Code 118.05)
   741.06 WASTE AND RECYCLING DISTRICTS AND COLLECTION SCHEDULE.
   (a)   The Waste and Recycling Districts shall be described as follows:
      (1)   District 1 - Monday or Tuesday. District 1 is described as follows:
Beginning at the northeast corner of the City; thence southerly along the east
corporation line to the centerline of Graham Road; thence westerly along the
centerline of Graham Road to the centerline of Darrow Road (S.R. 91); thence
northly along the centerline of Darrow Road to the north corporation line
(Norton Road); thence easterly along the north corporation line to the original
point of origin.
      (2)   District 2 - Tuesday or Wednesday. District 2 is described as
follows: Beginning at the southeast corner of the City; thence westerly along
the south corporation line to a point on the west corporation line (Englewood
Drive extended); thence northly along the west corporation line (Englewood
Drive) to the centerline of Graham Road; thence easterly along the centerline
of Graham Road to the east corporation line; thence southerly along the east
corporation line to the original point of beginning.
      (3)   District 3 - Wednesday or Thursday. District 3 is described as
follows: Beginning at the southwest corner of the City in the centerline of
Graham Road; thence northerly along the west corporation line to the
intersection of the north corporation line; thence easterly along the north
corporation line to the centerline of Darrow Road; thence southerly along the
centerline of Darrow Road to the centerline of Graham Road; thence westerly
along the centerline of Graham Road to the centerline of Englewood Drive;
thence generally westerly along the south corporation line to the original
point of beginning.
   (b)   Whoever violates this section is guilty of a fourth degree
misdemeanor. It is an affirmative defense to this section that the private
hauler was operating outside of the schedule set forth herein due to National
or State holiday, impossible roads due to snow or a mistake by the hauler in
missing an address on a scheduled day emergency pursuant to Section
351.14.
(Ord. 2007-247. Passed 12-13-07.)
   741.07 HOURS OF COLLECTION.
   (a)    No person, including a corporation shall engage, operate or permit
the operation of any business described in Section
741.01 between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.
   (b)   Whoever violates subsection (a) above shall be guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for a first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for each
subsequent offense.
   (c)   The Service Director, or his designated representative, shall have the
authority to suspend or revoke a license issued under Section
741.02 when the licensee is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree
pursuant to subsection (b) above.
   (d)   In the event the licensee has a license suspended or revoked, pursuant
to subsection (c) above, and the licensee desires to appeal, he shall timely
file written notice with the Safety Director within ten days after the receipt
of the order of revocation from the Service Director, or his designated
representative. Within thirty days of the filing of a notice of appeal, the
Safety Director shall hear, determine and in writing issue its decision as to
whether the revocation shall be sustained or overturned. The Safety Director
may apply other than the strict rules of evidence relating to hearsay evidence.
   (e)   Criminal remedies available under this section are in addition to and
not in replacement of other remedies available to the City under the Codified
Ordinances or any other law or regulation.
(Ord. 2009-73. Passed 3-26-09.)
   741.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which another penalty is
not already provided is guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor. Each day’s
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2005-173. Passed 10-13-05.)
CHAPTER 747
Secondhand Dealers
747.01   Secondhand dealers generally; licensed required.
747.02   License application requirements.
747.03   Inspection and tests of weights and measures.
747.04   License fee, term, renewal.
747.05   Temporary license application, term.
747.06   License transfer and display.
747.07   Change in ownership, interest, or employees.
747.08   License revocation, suspension, and appeal.
747.09   Reporting to LeadsOnline or similar entity.
747.10   Tagging of articles.
747.11   Change or removal of articles; holding period.
747.12   Purchases from minor; hours of operation.
747.13   Investigation by police.
747.14   Identity of seller or pawner.
747.15   Secondhand articles with unique identifiers.
747.16   Exceptions.
747.98   Severability.
747.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
      Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
      Record of transactions required - see Ohio R.C. 4737.01, 4737.04
      Dealing with minors prohibited; hours regulated - see Ohio R.C. 4737.03
   747.01    SECONDHAND DEALERS GENERALLY; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   For purposes of this chapter:
      (1)   "Pawnbroker" means a person, persons, society, club, partnership,
organization or corporation engaged in the business of lending money on deposit
or pledges of personal property, other than securities or printed evidence of
indebtedness, at a total charge, rate of interest, or discount or other
remuneration in excess of eight per cent annum at its business location within
the City of Stow.
      (2)   "Secondhand" means that which has been used or which has been
previously traded or sold by a retailer
      (3)   "Precious metals" means articles made of or containing gold,
silver, platinum, or other precious metals or jewels of any description.
Computer parts containing gold, silver or platinum including processors (CPUs),
RAMS, motherboards, hard drives, CD/DVD drives, etc. shall not be considered
"precious metals" for the purpose of this chapter.
      (4)   "Purchase" means the acquisition of second-hand articles for a
consideration of cash, goods, or other second-hand articles.
      (5)   "Secondhand dealer" means any person, persons, society, club,
partnership, organization or corporation engaged in the business of purchasing
secondhand articles for the purpose of resale if, in any manner, including any
form of advertisement, signage, electronic media, including electronic mail, or
other solicitation of customers, the dealer holds himself, herself, or itself
out to the public as willing to purchase secondhand articles from a seller, in
person, at its business location within the City of Stow.
 
   (b)   No person, partnership, corporation, or other entity, within the
corporation limits of the City of Stow, unless duly licensed as provided in
this chapter, shall engage in the business of a pawnbroker or in the business
of a secondhand dealer or advertise in any form to the public of the person or
entity's willingness to purchase the following "secondhand articles":
      (1)   Secondhand furs; or
      (2)   Secondhand computers, laptops, printers, copiers, or other office
machinery; or
      (3)   Pawnbrokers' tickets or other evidence of pledged articles; or
      (4)   Secondhand tools of artisans, mechanics, or common laborers; or
      (5)   Secondhand cameras; or
      (6)   Secondhand musical instruments or equipment, amplifiers, mixing
boards, etc.; or
      (7)   Secondhand precious metals, stones or jewels; or
      (8)   Secondhand televisions, video monitors, record players, tape
players, tape recorders, disc players or other stereo equipment, compact disks,
portable music players, headphones, tablets, video cassette recorders or other
video equipment, video game systems or other video game equipment, video game
cartridges or video game compact disks, cellular telephones, radio receivers or
transmitters, or other electronic media, toys, or devices; or
      (9)   Secondhand athletic equipment or fitness machinery or equipment; or
      (10)   Secondhand retailer gift cards or store credit; or
      (11)   Secondhand antique china, antique flatware or serving ware; or
      (12)   Secondhand weapons (except firearms), or yard equipment; or
      (13)   Secondhand designer items such as handbags and leather goods.
         (Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.02 LICENSE APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Every applicant for a license shall make an application in writing to
the Mayor or her designee, which application shall set forth the name under
which the business is to be conducted, the name of every person owning or
having an interest in the business, the name of any person to be employed in
the business, the location where the business is to be conducted, and the type
of secondhand articles to be purchased, sold, or exchanged. The application
must be made by the person who is to conduct or manage the business.
   (b)   No license shall be issued or renewed to any applicant if the
applicant, any of the persons owning or having an interest in the business, or
any employee of the business has been convicted of any felony or any crime
involving fraud, theft, receiving or possessing stolen property in the five
years immediately preceding the date of the license application. Applicants
shall grant the City of Stow authorization to run standard police background
investigations on the applicant, the owners and any employees of the to-be-
licensed business. The Mayor or her designee shall not issue a license until
all background checks are completed on persons required by this article.
Applicants denied a license may re-apply annually.
   (c)   Subsection (b) of this section shall not apply to applicants operating
a secondhand dealer business within the City of Stow as of the date this
chapter first became effective for a period of five years, provided that any
transfer in ownership or new employees hired by any such applicant after the
effective date of this chapter shall nonetheless be subject to subsection (b).
On the fifth anniversary of the effective date of this chapter, subsection (b)
shall apply to all Secondhand Dealer licensees and applicants with no
exception.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.03  INSPECTIONS AND TESTS OF WEIGHTS AND MEASURES.
   Every applicant for a secondhand dealer license who intends to trade in
precious stones or any manufactured article composed wholly or in part of gold,
silver, platinum, or other precious metal must obtain an inspection and test
from the Summit County Division of Weights and Measures of any and all scales,
balances, or other instruments and devices for weighing and measuring, and any
appliances and accessories associated with any or all such instruments and
devices used at the location indicated on the application. The Mayor or her
designee must receive a certification from the Weights and Measures
Superintendent that the required inspection and testing has taken place and
that the scales, balances, instruments, devices, appliances, and accessories
give a correct weight. The City shall not grant the application without the
proper certification. The certification issued by the Weights and Measures
Superintendent is valid only for the location indicated on the application. It
is not transferable to any other person, partnership, corporation, or any other
entity.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.04 LICENSE FEE, TERM, RENEWAL.
   (a)   The license fee, payable to the Mayor or her designee at the time of
application, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each business location. This
fee which is paid at the time of application is not refundable in any case. The
license shall expire biennially on December 31 of every odd numbered year. The
license shall contain the name under which the business is to be conducted and
the location where the business is to be conducted. Any new application
submitted within six months or less of the December 31 expiration date during
an odd numbered year, if thereafter approved, shall be valid for the next
biennial term.
   (b)   Applications for license renewals shall include authorizations to run
a criminal background check on all required persons pursuant to Section
747.02 and a fifty dollar ($50.00) non-refundable fee. Any licensee who fails
to renew a license on or before the date the license expires is prohibited from
acting as a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer until the license is renewed or a
new license is issued under this section.
   (c)   The Mayor or her designee shall create all initial license application
and renewal forms to be used in accordance with this chapter, with the Law
Director's approval.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.05 TEMPORARY LICENSE APPLICATION, TERM.
   (a)   A secondhand dealer shall be considered "temporary" when the dealer
engages in the business activities described in
747.01(b) within the City's borders for a total of fourteen days or less within
a period of six consecutive months. All temporary secondhand dealers must first
be duly licensed under the provisions of this Chapter before engaging in the
business
747.01. Temporary secondhand dealers shall be subject to all of the same
requirements under Chapter
747 except that:
      (1)   Temporary licenses shall only be valid for the dates the applicant
plans to conduct such business within the City, which shall be prominently
displayed on the license; and
      (2)   Temporary licensees may comply with Section
747.09 by either subscribing to LeadsOnline or other electronic reporting
system in use by the City or by keeping written records of all transactions
that would have otherwise been entered in the electronic reporting system and
submitting copies of such records to the Stow Police Department within twenty-
four (24) hours of completing the transaction(s) during the term of the
temporary license. If a temporary licensee uses written records, such records
shall contain all the same information required on the electronic reporting
system in use by the City of Stow.
   (b)   Any secondhand dealer that does not qualify as temporary shall be
considered permanent and shall not be subject to this provision. The Mayor or
her designee shall create all temporary license application forms to be used in
accordance with this chapter, with the Law Director's approval. (Ord. 2017-65.
Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.06 LICENSE TRANSFER AND DISPLAY.
   Licenses issued under this chapter shall not be transferable to any person,
partnership, corporation, or other entity and the business may be conducted
only at the location for which the license is issued. The license must be so
placed as to be made conspicuously visible.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.07 CHANGE IN OWNERSHIP, INTEREST, OR EMPLOYEES.
   Every licensee, under the provisions of this chapter, shall inform the
Police Department in writing, within ten business days of any significant
change in persons owning or having an interest in the business. For purposes of
this section, a significant change in business ownership shall mean a transfer
or change of thirty percent (30%) or more of ownership rights in the business.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.08 LICENSE REVOCATION, SUSPENSION, AND APPEAL.
   (a)   The conviction of any licensee under the provisions of this chapter,
any person owning or having an interest in the business, or any employee of a
business licensed under this article, for any felony or for any crime involving
fraud, theft, receiving, or possessing stolen property shall constitute grounds
for immediate revocation or suspension by the Mayor or her designee of the
license issued to such business. Any violation of a provision of this chapter
or any false statement made by the applicant in connection with the issuance of
this license shall also constitute grounds for immediate revocation or
suspension by the Mayor or her designee of the license issued to such business
regardless of whether the licensee or any employee of licensee is criminally
charged or convicted for said violation or false statement.
   (b)   Licensee shall be notified promptly, in writing sent via certified
mail, of any decision to revoke or suspend his or her license and of the
licensee's right to appeal the decision. Notice may be sent by regular mail
after any previous notice sent by certified mail is returned unclaimed.
Licensee may appeal a revocation or suspension of his or her license by
submitting a request to appeal, in writing, to the Mayor within thirty (30)
days of receiving the notice of revocation or suspension if sent by certified
mail, or within thirty (30) days of the date the City sent the notice of
revocation or suspension if sent by regular mail. If licensee timely requests
an appeal, a hearing shall be held before the Mayor within thirty (30) days of
the date the City received the licensee's request to appeal. The licensee shall
have the right to appear at such hearing, to be represented by counsel, and
have the right to examine and cross examine witnesses. In the event of a
decision and ruling adverse to the licensee, the licensee, unless otherwise
expressly provided, shall have the right to appeal such decision and ruling to
a court of competent jurisdiction, under the authority of and pursuant to the
provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 2506.
   (c)   Whenever, for any cause, a license is revoked or suspended, the City
of Stow shall not issue another license to the licensee nor to the husband or
wife of the licensee, nor to any copartnership or corporation of which the
licensee is an officer, nor to any person employed by the licensee, until the
expiration of at least one year from the date of revocation of the license.
   (d)   Persons or entities continuing to operate as a pawnbroker or
secondhand dealer after a license has been denied, suspended, or revoked
pursuant to this chapter may be served with a cease and desist order issued by
a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.09 REPORTING TO LEADSONLINE OR SIMILAR ENTITY.
   (a)   The City of Stow Police Department shall enter into a contract for
services and maintain its contract for services with LeadsOnline or a similar
entity in order to enhance its investigative services to protect both
secondhand dealers and members of the general public. In the event of a change
to its electronic reporting system, the city shall notify all licensed
secondhand dealers in the city of the change within a reasonable time prior to
such change.
 
   (b)   Every secondhand dealer shall own, operate or maintain reliable access
to a functioning computer system with internet access for the purposes
described herein. Every secondhand dealer shall subscribe to LeadsOnline or the
city's current electronic reporting system and maintain said subscription
throughout the term of the secondhand dealer's license.
   (c)   Every secondhand dealer shall furnish a report of any and every
secondhand article, as described in Section
747.01(b), taken in pawn or purchased by such secondhand dealer as soon as
reasonably possible after the transaction is consummated, but no later than the
following business day, by uploading such report to the LeadsOnline program or
the electronic system then in use by the city via a secure internet connection.
For every report, the secondhand dealer shall input information to every data
field supported by the LeadsOnline system or the system then currently in use
by the Stow Police Department. No entry into the system shall be erased or
tampered with by the secondhand dealer or any person.
   (d)   No item shall be purchased unless the person from whom the article is
acquired exhibits a valid government issued photo identification card such as a
driver's license, state-issued identification card, military identification
card, or United States passport and the identifying numbers from said
identification card are recorded on the electronic report submitted to
LeadsOnline or the electronic system then in use by the city.
   (e)   If any article that is left on deposit, pledged or purchased has
engraved thereon a number, word or initials or contains settings of any kind,
the description of the article in the electronic report shall contain the
number, word or initials engraved and shall describe the setting of the item
and the number of each kind.
   (f)   Every secondhand dealer shall furnish a photograph of every article of
jewelry, precious metal, or stone, regardless of value, taken in pawn,
purchased or accepted by such secondhand dealer, as soon as reasonably possible
after the transaction is consummated, but no later than the following business
day, by uploading the photograph to the LeadsOnline or other program via a
secure internet connection.
   (g)   In the event the electronic reporting system malfunctions or is
otherwise not operational, the secondhand dealer shall, at all times during
such malfunction or non-operation, keep written records of any and all
transactions that would have otherwise been entered in the electronic reporting
system and shall submit such records to the Stow Police Department within
twenty-four (24) hours of such transaction during the nonoperational period.
The written records shall contain all information required on the electronic
reporting system.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.10 TAGGING OF ARTICLES.
   Every licensee under the provisions of this chapter, at the time of
acquiring through purchase or exchange any secondhand article, shall attach a
tag or label with a designating number thereon, legibly printed, in ink, in the
English language, to each article, and shall make an entry of such number in
LeadsOnline or similar entity as required by Section
747.08. Once tagged or labeled appropriately, the licensee shall place the
tagged article into a separate holding area pursuant to Section
747.10 until such time as the article can be sold.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.11 CHANGE OR REMOVAL OF ARTICLES; HOLDING PERIOD.
   (a)   No licensee under the provisions of this chapter or agent or employee
thereof shall disassemble, take apart, change the form of, sell, or remove from
the corporation limits of the city any of the goods, articles, or things sold
to him, which are set forth in Section
747.01(b) until the same have been in his possession at least fourteen (14)
days, starting from the day in which the item(s) are reported and uploaded to
the LeadsOnline program or the electronic system then in use by the City.
   Notwithstanding the fourteen-day holding period, a licensee may release an
article to the seller in accordance with state law prior to fourteen days from
receipt of the item.
   (b)   A licensee may apply to the Mayor or her designee for a waiver of or
modification to the holding period requirement within this section if licensee
can demonstrate that the recently purchased second hand articles are accessible
to licensee during the 14 day holding period and can feasibly be delivered or
provided to City of Stow Police Department within 48 hours' notice.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
 
   747.12 PURCHASES FROM MINORS; HOURS OF OPERATION.
   (a)   No person shall receive, by sale, barter, exchange, or otherwise, any
article mentioned in this chapter from a minor under the age of eighteen years.
Whenever a secondhand dealer has reason to know or believe the seller or
exchanger is under eighteen years of age, he or she must require that person to
produce sufficient articles of identification to establish his or her age.
   (b)   There shall not be any purchase from any person or persons between the
hours of 11:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any day of the week.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.13 INVESTIGATION BY POLICE.
   (a)   If any City Law Enforcement Officer has probable cause to believe that
the item(s) described in the reports provided for under this chapter is stolen
property, the City Law Enforcement Officer shall notify the secondhand dealer
in writing, and upon receipt of such notice, the secondhand dealer shall retain
such item(s) until the expiration a reasonable period of time to conduct an
investigation has elapsed, such time shall not be less than thirty (30) days
after the day on which the secondhand dealer first uploaded the required
information onto the LeadsOnline program or similar system provided for under
this chapter, unless the City Law Enforcement Officer notifies the secondhand
dealer in writing that retention is not required until such expiration.
   (b)   Every licensee shall immediately report to the Stow Police Department
any article or thing pledged or sold to it; or which is sought to be pledged or
sold to it, if it has reason to believe that the article or thing was stolen or
lost.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.14 IDENTITY OF SELLER OR PAWNER.
   (a)   No person shall sell, exchange or pawn a secondhand article on behalf
of another person without providing the name, residence or street address, and
birth date of the person for whom the item is being exchanged, pawned or sold.
   (b)   No person shall sell, exchange, or pawn a secondhand article on behalf
of another person if the person for whom the item being pawned is not eligible
to conduct the exchange, pawn or sale or to conceal that the item is or may be
stolen.
   (c)   No person shall use or provide a fictitious or false name or address,
or provide false or fictitious information when selling, pledging, or
exchanging any secondhand article with a secondhand dealer. (Ord. 2017-65.
Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.15 SECONDHAND ARTICLES WITH UNIQUE IDENTIFIERS.
   No secondhand dealer shall purchase, trade, or accept for pawn any
secondhand article known to be manufactured with a serial number or similar
identifier if the serial number or other identifier has been altered,
obstructed or removed.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.16 EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to:
   (a)   Persons who deal exclusively in furniture; or
   (b)   Persons who deal exclusively in secondhand automobiles or automobile
parts; or
   (c)   Persons who deal exclusively in clothing, except furs or leather; or
   (d)   Any purchase of precious metals, jewels, or stones of any description
if both the buyer and seller, or the respective agents, brokers, or other
intermediaries of both the buyer and seller, deal in such articles or otherwise
by their respective occupations; or
   (e)   Any transactions involving the sale or transfer of precious metals by
a wholesale jeweler to a retail jeweler or licensed dealer; or
   (f)   National banks, state banks, credit unions, or savings and loan
associations; or
   (g)   Any person doing business under the laws of Ohio or the United States
relating to any broker-dealer, commodity futures commission merchant, or
commodity trading advisor or agent duly registered and regulated by the
division of securities under Chapter 1707 of the Ohio Revised Code or the
United States commodity futures trading commission under 7 U.S.C. 1 et seq.; or
   (h)   Transactions of five or fewer compact disks, video game cartridges
and/or video game compact disks when store credit, and not money, is given for
these items; or
   (i)   Infrequent sales conducted as garage or yard sales held in accordance
with the provisions of Section
1185.02(c)(2)A. of this Code; or
   (j)   Sales by religious or 501(C)(3) Charitable Organizations; or
   (k)   Cellular phone returns or exchanges with a wireless telecommunications
service provider pursuant to an existing service contract or subscription
whereupon store credit is given to the person returning or exchanging his or
her personal cellular phone and is used to obtain a new or upgraded cellular
phone serviced by the same wireless telecommunications service provider; or
   (l)   Returns or exchanges of defective or unwanted items to the same retail
chain or store location where the item was bought for a full cash refund or
store credit; or
   (m)   Donations of secondhand articles whereupon no money, credit, items or
services are offered in exchange; or
   (n)   Sales of scrap automobile parts or industrial metals not otherwise
specifically listed in
747.01(b); or
   (o)   Coins or hallmark bars. (Ord. 2016-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.98 SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this Chapter is determined by a court of competent
jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, that determination shall not
affect any other provision, each of which shall remain valid and enforceable as
if the invalid or unenforceable portion were not contained herein. (Ord. 2017-
65. Passed 8-10-17.)
   747.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever recklessly violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor of the third degree for a first offense. Any subsequent violation
of this chapter by the same person shall be punishable as a misdemeanor of the
first degree.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 8-10-17.)
CHAPTER 755
Taxicabs
755.01   Definitions.
755.02   Operator's license required; fee.
755.03   License application.
755.04   License issuance.
755.05   Taxicab stands.
755.06   Display of rates; excessive charges.
755.07   Rates.
755.08   Driver's license required.
755.09   Periodic review and inspection.
755.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
      Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
      Chauffeur's license not required - see Ohio R.C. 4501.01(y)
      Operation by minor prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 4507.321
      Operation and equipment - see TRAF. Ch.
337
   755.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter:
   (a)   "Taxicab" means any vehicle whose owner or driver solicits, secures or
accepts passengers for hire upon hail or request on the streets of the City.
   (b)   "Taxicab service" means any business established for the purpose of
operating taxicabs and the transportation of passengers for hire for departure
from the City or delivery to the City, or points of departure or arrival
located therein, excluding therefrom limousine services.
      (Ord. 1985-155. Passed 4-25-85.)
   755.02 OPERATOR'S LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall operate or cause to be operated a taxicab or proffer the
service of any vehicle as a taxicab unless the owner of that vehicle has
obtained a taxicab license as provided in this chapter. Every such taxicab
license shall be issued on or before June 30 of the year in which issued.
Licenses issued on or after December 1st of any year shall be issued at one-
half the annual license fee provided herein. Applicants for renewal shall be
submitted on or before April 1 of each year.
   (a)   Resident Business License
      (1)   A resident taxicab business shall be one whose principal place of
business is in the City or which desires to serve City residents on a
nonrestrictive, full-time basis.
      (2)   The annual license fee for each resident taxicab shall be twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) for the first taxicab owned by any person applying for a
resident business license and ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional taxicab.
The license fee shall be paid at the time of application for a license and
fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be refunded in the event that a license is
denied.
      (3)   A five dollar ($5.00) per vehicle inspection fee shall be charged
when such vehicles are inspected by the City.
      (4)   A one dollar ($1.00) per operator charge shall be collected for the
City Police Department's driving record check of the owner and or employee for
whom a driving record check is run.
   (b)   Nonresident Limited Business License. 
      (1)   A nonresident taxicab business shall be one whose principal place
of business is located outside the City and which desires to serve City
residents on a restrictive, part-time basis.
      (2)   Council shall set forth limits and restrictions in the license
granted based upon the requested extent of service desired to be rendered by
the applicant as enumerated in his application for license.
      (3)   The annual license fee for each nonresident taxicab company shall
be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) regardless of date of issuance or the number of
taxicabs operated in the City.
      (4)   A five dollar ($5.00) per vehicle inspection fee shall be charged
when such vehicles are inspected by the City.
      (5)   A one dollar ($1.00) per operator charge shall be collected for the
City Police Department's driving record check of the owner and or employee for
whom a driving record check is run.
         (Ord. 1985-155. Passed 4-25-85.)
   755.03 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Each applicant for a taxicab license shall present and file with the
Department of Public Service a signed application setting forth the trade name
under which he intends to do business, the number of vehicles and a general
description of each vehicle for which the license is desired, the marking or
lettering to be used thereon, enumeration of all drivers proposed to operate
licensed taxicabs within the City, and any other information required by the
Department of Public Service pertinent to the issuance of the license.
(1979 Code 120.03)
   755.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   (a)   The Public Improvements Committee of Council shall investigate and
hold a hearing upon each application for a license. If the Committee finds upon
the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity do not
justify the operation of the vehicle for which a license is desired, it shall
forthwith notify the applicant of its findings and report such findings to
Council If the Committee finds upon the investigation and hearing that the
public convenience and necessity do justify the operation of the vehicle for
which a license is desired, it shall forthwith notify the applicant. Within
sixty days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish and file with the Department
of Public Service the following:
      (1)    A full transcript of the information appearing on the certificate
of title of each vehicle for which a license is desired and the state license
number of each such vehicle.
      (2)   An official, unexpired certificate from the Chief of Police stating
that each vehicle for which a license is desired has been annually inspected
and tested and found to meet the standards fixed by statute and that each such
vehicle is roadworthy and safe for operation as a taxicab.
         A.   The report of any municipal police department which has similarly
inspected the vehicle may be accepted by the Chief of Police as being in
compliance with this subsection (a)(2) hereof, in the event the report is no
older than thirty days.
         B.   A report from the State Highway Patrol regarding the inspection
and approval of such vehicle may also be accepted by the Chief of Police as
being in compliance with this subsection (a)(2) hereof, in the event the report
is no older than thirty days.
         C.   Nothing contained herein shall preclude the Chief of Police from
requiring commercial, computerized or other scientific evaluation of the
vehicle, at the applicant's cost, to assure that all mechanical systems are
roadworthy and safe for operation as a taxicab.
      (3)   The name of each person who will or may operate the taxicab in the
City and the driver's license number of such person.
      (4)   A policy of liability insurance issued for the life of the license
applied for or longer by a responsible insurance company.
         The policy shall be approved as to sufficiency by the Director of
Finance and as to legality by the Law Director and shall provide indemnity for
or protection to the applicant against losses resulting from the operation of
each such taxicab to the extent of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) for the
injury or death of one person in any one accident, one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) for the injury or death of more than one person in any one accident
and ten thousand dollars ($10,000) for property damage caused in any one
accident. In lieu of the insurance policy described herein the applicant may
furnish a bond binding the principal and sureties to liability for payment of a
judgment to the extent of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000), one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000) and ten thousand dollars ($10,000) respectively as
set forth above with at least two approved persons as sureties or one approved
corporate surety. The bond shall be approved as to sufficiency by the Director
of Finance and as to legality by the Law Director.
      (5)   The schedule of rates and rates to be charged passengers for
transportation during the period of the license.
      (6)   A record of all transports originating in the City or terminating
within the City for the year immediately preceding the application.
   (b)   Thereupon, Council as a whole may examine the supporting information
and documents or receive a report thereon from the City Administration. Upon
satisfaction that the applicant is the owner of any such vehicle, that the
vehicle is a safe and fit conveyance, the drivers to be authorized under the
permit have satisfactory driving histories as certified by the Chief of Police,
and that a satisfactory insurance policy or bond has been issued and is in
force thereon, it shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, authorize
the issuance of a license to the applicant by the Department of Public Service.
A certified copy of the license shall be exhibited in a prominent place in each
taxicab at all times.
(1985 -155. Passed 4-25-85.)
   755.05 TAXICAB STANDS.
   At the time the license is issued, the Mayor and the Public Improvements
Committee may designate regular parking spaces for the taxicabs and may
prescribe rules for the usage of these stands suitable to the applicant's
business and agreeable with the public convenience and welfare.
(1979 Code 120.05)
   755.06 DISPLAY OF RATES; EXCESSIVE CHARGES.
   (a)   Every taxicab business shall display at all times a printed list of
the fares and rates to be charged passengers for transportation, which fares
and rates shall not be in excess of the schedule furnished the City under
Section
755.04(a)(5), except when an increase in rates is approved by Council.
   (b)   Every licensed taxicab shall display, on its exterior, rear vehicle,
such decal as the City may require and issue as evidence that the vehicle on
which such license or decal is affixed is licensed by the City to provide
taxicab services, which decal shall be visible at all times at a distance of
twenty-five feet.
   (c)   Every licensed taxicab driver shall display, on the interior of his
taxicab, at a location plainly visible to his passengers, a photographic,
identification noting the company with which he is licensed to drive, his name,
address and date of his taxicab licensure.
(Ord. 1985-155. Passed 4-25-85.)
   755.07 RATES.
   The minimum amount of fares and rates which may be charged for taxicab
transportation to and from various points of origin and destination within the
City shall be as established from time to time by Council.
(1979 Code 120.07)
   755.08 DRIVER'S LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall drive a taxicab unless he has secured a driver's
license as provided in this section and his driving record has been reviewed
and approved by the Police Department.
   (b)   No such license shall be issued to any person who is not familiar with
the traffic laws and ordinances of the City. The Chief of Police shall examine
each applicant for a taxicab driver's license to determine the competency of
the applicant, and no such license shall be issued except upon a certificate
from the Chief that the applicant has demonstrated his ability to consistently
and safely operate, based upon his past driving records and any other facts
available to the Police Department, a vehicle operated for the public
convenience. In lieu of the demonstration, the Chief may accept certification
of such ability from another municipal police department. Each driver shall be
of good moral character and repute and possess a satisfactory driving history.
   (c)   Council may revoke any taxicab driver's license or any taxicab
business license for repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances or of
any ordinance regulating the conduct of the drivers; and may revoke the
authorization of any previously approved driver to operate such a taxicab based
upon an advanced driving record either prior to the issuance of the license or
occuring during the period of the license.
(1979 Code 120.08)
   755.09 PERIODIC REVIEW AND INSPECTION.
   (a)   Nothing contained herein shall preclude the City, during the course of
any licensed year, to conduct or require periodic inspection of the vehicles to
assure their continued roadworthyness and safety, and nor shall any provision
preclude the City from periodically evaluating the driver's records or status
of licensed drivers of such taxicab companies to assure their continued safe
driving habits.
   (b)   On request of the Director of Public Service, each taxicab service
shall submit a monthly record of transports originating or terminating in the
City.
(Ord. 1985-155. Passed 4-25-85.)
   755.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which another penalty is
not already provided is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
CHAPTER 759
Medical Marijuana
759.01   Definitions.
759.02   Ban.
CROSS REFERENCES
Drug abuse - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
513
   759.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, “medical marijuana” shall have the same
meaning as that term is defined in Ohio R.C. 3796.01(A)(2) as adopted by H.B.
523.
(Ord. 2017-87. Passed 7-27-17.)
   759.02 BAN.
   (a)   Council establishes permanent ban on the acceptance of any application
for, or the granting of, any zoning certificate for any building, structure,
use, expansion of use or change of use that would enable the cultivation,
processing, distribution or sale of medical marijuana in the City.
   (b)   No existing business in the City may expand in any way that would
establish the cultivation, processing, distribution or sale of medical
marijuana.
   (c)   This chapter does not limit research related to marijuana conducted at
a state university, academic medical center, or private research and
development organization as part of a research protocol approved by an
institutional review board or equivalent entity.
(Ord. 2017-87. Passed 7-27-17.)

CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF STOW
PART NINE - STREETS, UTILITIES AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE
TITLE ONE - Street and Sidewalk Areas
            Chap.
901.    Excavations.
            Chap.
903. Annual Road Plan.
            Chap.
905.    Culverts, Curb Cuts and Driveways.

CHAPTER 901
Excavations
901.01   Permit required.
901.02   Permit application.
901.03   Permit issuance.
901.04   Permit conditions.
901.05   Exceptions.
901.06   Supervision by Public Service Director.
901.07   Obstruction of public ways.
901.08   Restoration.
901.09   Noncompliance; remedy of City.
901.10   Construction and reconstruction of utility facilities.
901.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Liability for damage - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
      Changing established grade - see Ohio R.C. 727.07
      Digging, excavating and piling dirt on street - see Ohio R.C. 5589.10
      Barricades and warning lights - see GEN. OFF.
521.03
   901.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person shall make any type of excavation in or on any street,
alley, sidewalk or public ground for any purpose whatsoever, or remove the
surface of any street within its right of way without obtaining a permit as
provided in this chapter.
   (b)    For all underground utility improvements to be installed within the
public right- of-way, applicant shall deposit with the City an amount deemed
necessary by the Director of Public Service, in no case being less than one
hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00), prior to the issuance of a permit.
      (1)    This deposit shall be determined based upon expected costs to be
incurred by the City, including, but not limited to, plan review and on-site
inspections. These costs shall be deducted from the required deposit, above the
minimum one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) which is non-refundable.
      (2)    The Director of Public Service reserves the right to require
additional deposit should the initial deposit be insufficient to cover costs
incurred by the City.
      (3)    These funds are to be held in the separate construction trust fund
by Director of Finance, and the remaining deposit, if any, shall be disbursed
to the applicant upon notification of the completion of permitted work within
thirty (30) days.
      (4)    At the discretion of the City Engineer, applicants shall be
required to remove underground utilities within the public right-of-way when
abandoned or when use otherwise ceases.
         (Ord. 2025-043. Passed 2-20-25.)
   901.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Application for a permit required by Section
901.01 shall be made at the office of the Director of Public Service on forms
provided by him. The application shall show:
   (a)   The name and address of the owner or agent in charge of the property
abutting the proposed work area;
   (b)   The name and address of the party doing the work;
   (c)   The location of the work area;
   (d)   The estimated cost of the alteration; and
   (e)   Such other information as the Director finds necessary.
      (1979 Code 97.02)
   901.03 PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   The Director of Public Service shall issue a permit hereunder when he finds:
   (a)   The work will be done according to the standard specifications of the
City for public work of like character;
   (b)   The operation will not unreasonably interfere with vehicular and
pedestrian traffic, the demand and necessity for parking spaces, and the means
of ingress and egress to and from the property affected and adjacent
properties; and
   (c)   The health, welfare and safety of the public will not be unreasonably
impaired.
      (1979 Code 97.03)
   901.04 PERMIT CONDITIONS.
   In addition to the contents of the application as specified in Section
901.02, the Director of Public Service, as a condition precedent to the
granting of any permit, may require the applicant:
   (a)   To submit plans or a sketch indicating the location, size type and
duration of the excavation or removal contemplated;
   (b)   To conform with the methods of excavating, refilling and resurfacing
to be followed;
   (c)   To use those warning devices as the Director deems necessary to
protect users of the street, alley, sidewalk or public ground and abutting
property;
   (d)   To make a deposit in an amount that the Director deems necessary, in
no case being less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or post a bond, or both,
to indemnify the City against damage as a result of the excavation or to be
used to offset required inspection service costs that result from noncompliance
to City standards. In the event the conditions of the permit are not fulfilled
or the City right of way is not restored to its original condition, the
applicant shall be given notice to make the necessary corrections and if such
corrections are not made, the City shall perform the necessary work. The
applicant shall pay for all labor and material costs associated with such work,
as well as any extra inspection costs. These costs may be deducted from the
required deposit. These funds are to be held in the separate construction trust
fund by the Director of Finance.
   (e)   To pay a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per utility to cover the cost
of the issuance of the permit and the cost of routine on-site inspection
services.
      (1979 Code 97.04)
   901.05 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any federal, state, county
or municipal employee authorized to engage in that work, or in the case of any
emergency, requiring immediate action to protect the public health, safety or
welfare.
(1979 Code 97.05)
   901.06 SUPERVISION BY PUBLIC SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   All operations for which a permit is granted hereunder shall be supervised
by the Director of Public Service.
(1979 Code 97.06)
   901.07 OBSTRUCTION OF PUBLIC WAYS.
   In removing pavement or other material from any street, alley, sidewalk or
public ground, for any purpose whatsoever, the material dug up shall be
deposited in such manner as to guard against inconvenience to the public by
obstructing any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground.
(1979 Code 97.07)
   901.08 RESTORATION.
   All places where pavement or other material is removed from any street,
alley, sidewalk or public ground shall be restored to their former condition as
speedily as practicable, either by the City or by the person causing the
pavement to be removed, as may be directed, but at the cost and expense of the
person causing the pavement to be removed.
(1979 Code 97.08)
   901.09 NONCOMPLIANCE; REMEDY OF CITY.
   Should the permittee fail or refuse to restore the street, alley, sidewalk
or public ground to the specification required by the Director of Public
Service, the Street Commissioner shall attend the restoration. The Director is
authorized to deduct, upon the statement of the Street Commissioner, the
reasonable cost of restoration and the cost of on-site inspection services at
rates prescribed in the latest contract, ordinance or resolution providing for
the services of the City Inspector from the deposit provided for in Section
901.04 and return the balance, if any, to the permittee. The remedy herein
shall be in addition to the penalty provided in Section
901.99.
(1979 Code 97.09)
   901.10 CONSTRUCTION AND RECONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES.
   (a)   No person shall construct, reconstruct or extend along a street, alley
or any public ground within the City any utilities without obtaining a permit
from the Department of Public Service. A utility is one of the following:
sewer, water, storm sewer, electric, natural gas, telephone, television or a
facility of similar nature. Before a permit is issued, if the Director of
Public Service deems it necessary, the applicant shall file plans and
specifications which show the course and route of the proposed utility
facilities within the City, the exact nature of the utility to be constructed,
the material, appurtenances and apparatus to be used in the construction, the
location and depth thereof and the kind and amount of energy to be transmitted,
if applicable, together with detailed specifications of the method of
transmitting or conducting the utility, and require a deposit as per Section
901.04(d). The fee for the permit shall be thirty dollars ($30.00). The release
of the deposit shall be conditioned upon the proper performance of all
conditions of the permit, if granted. Noncompliance with the conditions of the
permit shall be treated as in Section
901.04(d).
   (b)   Utilities constructed or extended to serve a new subdivision shall
comply with the City Subdivision Regulations.
   (c)   In the event emergency repairs are necessary, the work shall be
undertaken immediately and the office of the Director of Public Service shall
be notified as soon as possible of such work and a permit shall be issued
subsequent to the beginning of such repair work. Public utility companies shall
not be required to obtain a permit to work in the City right of way to perform
emergency repairs, although they are required to restore the right of way to
its original condition and to notify the City safety forces of such work.
   (d)   No permit for the construction or reconstruction of utility facilities
shall be granted if Council or the Director finds that the construction or
reconstruction would:
      (1)   Unreasonably impair the safety of the inhabitants of the City, the
general motoring public or the owners of property abutting on the streets and
ways on which the facilities are to be installed;
      (2)   Violate generally accepted standards of safe construction; or
      (3)   Otherwise adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare.
   (e)   Should Council or the Director fail to act upon an application for a
permit within thirty days after its filing, the application shall be deemed
granted and the permit deemed issued.
(1979 Code 97.10)
   901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree.
CHAPTER 903
Annual Road Plan
903.01   Comprehensive road plan.
903.02      Annual Pavement Crack Seal Program.
   903.01 COMPREHENSIVE ROAD PLAN.
   (a)    The comprehensive road plan shall be comprised of two (2) separate
plans: a Road Maintenance Plan and a Road Improvement Plan. Each plan has a
separate purpose and different components, but collectively, both will
represent a single management plan that will ensure the City’s transportation
system is properly and well maintained.
   (b)    The comprehensive road plan will serve as a tool that allows the City
to look forward to the future to continually evaluate and improve our
transportation system.
   (c)    To facilitate the preparation of a Comprehensive Road Plan, the City
may retain the services of such professionals and/or expert consultants from
time-to-time to formulate/update a reliable Comprehensive Road Plan.
   (d)    The Mayor shall annually furnish and present to the City Council, a
Comprehensive Road Plan to be included with the submission of the annual budget
referred to in
Article III § 4 of the Stow City Charter.
   (e)    The Comprehensive Road Plan at the minimum shall contain the
following:
      (1)    A Pavement Condition Rating (PCR) Report performed in accordance
with the Ohio Department of Transportation’s Pavement Condition Rating Manual.
         A.   That a Pavement Condition Rating (PCR) be performed beginning
every three (3) years from the most current year rating performed.
         B.   The PCR shall be performed by professionals and/or expert
consultants and shall be selected using Ohio’s Qualification-Based Selection
(QBS) pursuant to Ohio Revised Code §153.65-.73.
      (2)    A street inventory containing at a minimum, the following
information:
         A.   Street names.
         B.   Approximate pavement length.
         C.   Pavement width and area.
         D.   Pavement limits.
         E.   Right-of-way width.
F.   Recent year repaved, reconstructed, maintained, etc.
         G.   Road type (local, collector, arterial, etc.).
         H.   Type of existing pavement structure (concrete, asphalt, chip
seal, gravel, etc.).
         I.   Drive apron dimensions and area.
         J.   Sidewalk, curb, curb and gutter, curb ramps and castings.
         K.   Guardrail.
         L.   Striping.
      (3)    A listing of roads expected to be reconstructed, repaired, and
maintained for each construction and repair season.
      (4)    The anticipated available funding for the upcoming paving and road
maintenance season.
      (5)    The funding mechanisms and/or means by which the anticipated and
upcoming road repairs will be funded.
      (6)    A five (5)-year Road Project Plan that prioritizes all roads and
estimated costs and funding mechanisms by year.
      
   (f)    Annually, the Administration and City Council shall determine the
method and funding to accomplish the work set forth in the Annual Road Plan for
the ensuing year.
   
   (g)    While the Comprehensive Road Plan is updated annually and subject to
change as emergencies arise or projects are delayed by circumstances beyond our
control, the annual focus primarily will be on the fifth (5th) year of the plan
as new projects are added. The first year of the plan is the basis for actual
appropriations authorized by the City Council for road projects when adopting
the Annual Budget. The remaining four (4) years establish priorities for future
road improvement projects.
(Ord. 2022-200. Passed 1-26-23.)
   903.02 ANNUAL PAVEMENT CRACK SEAL PROGRAM. 
   (a)    This Annual Pavement Crack Seal Program (Program) consists of crack
sealing city streets pursuant to the most current version of the State of Ohio,
Department of Transportation’s Construction and Material Specifications, Item
423 Crack Sealing, Hot Applied, Type IV.
   (b)    This Program will be located at various locations throughout the
municipality. The duration of crack sealing under this Program will be
determined by the Director of Public Service but shall take place sometime
between early June and mid-September and will take several weeks to complete.
   (c)    That each road and section be its own separate line item in the
bidding process paid on a ‘Lump Sum’ basis and shall follow the following
example or similar format as shown below:

   (d)    The price bid for each item cover and shall be considered full

details and specifications and shall include but not limited to:
      (1)    All labor, materials, tools, equipment, and transportation
necessary for the proper execution of the work in accordance with the contract
documents and as necessary to comply with local, state, and federal codes.
      (2)    Project coordination and scheduling.
      (3)    All provisions to protect workers, the general public, and
property along the work area.
      (4)    Reimbursement to City for costs of re-inspection or re-testing of
any work not installed in compliance with the contract documents.
      (5)    Maintenance of traffic.
      (6)    Mobilization/Demobilization.
      (7)    Bonds and Insurances.
      (8)    Any and all cleaning, joint sealing, etc.
   (e)    That beginning January 1, 2023, and continuing thereafter, the
Program shall be funded using revenue generated by the City’s Street
Construction Fund. The Program shall be funded in the amount of two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000.00) each calendar year subject to revision by City
Council in accordance with this section.
      (1)    Each year of this Programs existence, City streets shall be crack

Section
